column1: I think there are three reasons, two long-term ones and the trigger.

column2: Ẹ sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́na-ẹgbẹ̀rún kan ènìyàn.

column1: It looks enormous, but the population of the European Union is 550 million people, which means we are talking about one per every [550] Europeans.
column2: Ó jọ bi ẹní pọ̀, ṣùgbọ́n àpapọ̀ ènìyàn ni Àjọ-ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́na-ẹgbẹ̀rún ọ̀tà-dín-léwà-dín-lẹ́gbẹ̀ta àwọn ènìyàn, tó túmọ̀ sí wí pé à ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ọ̀kan nínú gbogbo [ọ̀tà-dín-léwà-dín-lẹ́gbẹ̀ta] àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Europe.

column1: Now, in Lebanon, we have one refugee per three Lebanese.
column2: Báyìí, ní Lebanon, a ní atìpó kan nínú ọmọ orílẹ̀ ède Lebanon mẹ́ta.

column1: And Lebanon?
column2: Orílẹ̀-ède Lebanon ńkọ́?

column1: Struggling, of course, but it's managing.
column2: Ó ń tiraka, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ṣùgbọ́n ó ń gbìyànjú.

column1: So, the question is: is this something that could have been managed if -- not mentioning the most important thing, which would have been addressing the root causes, but forgetting about root causes for now, looking at the phenomenon as it is -- if Europe were able to come together in solidarity to create an adequate reception capacity of entry points?
column2: Nítorí náà, ìbéèrè náà ni wí pé: nǹkan yìí ni wọn ò bá ti ṣàmójútó rẹ̀ tó bá ṣe wí pe -- láìmẹ́nu ba nǹkan tó ṣe pàtàkì jùlọ, tí ò bá ti yanjú okùnfa ìpìlẹ rẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n ká gbàgbé nípa okùnfà ìpìlẹ rẹ̀ báyì, bí a ṣé ń wo nǹkan náà bó ṣe rí yìí -- tí ilẹ̀ Europe bá lè parapọ̀ ní ìṣọ̀kan láti pèse àyè ìgbàlejò tó péye ní àwọn ọ̀nà àbáwọlé ńkọ́?

column1: But for that, the countries at entry points need to be massively supported, and then screening the people with security checks and all the other mechanisms, distributing those that are coming into all European countries, according to the possibilities of each country.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́ fún ìyẹn, àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó wà ní àwọn ọ̀nà àbáwọlé nílò ìràlọ́wọ́ tó pọ̀, àti ṣíṣe àyẹ̀wò fún àwọn ènìyàn náà pẹ̀lú àyẹ̀wò ajẹmọ́-ààbò àti gbogbo àwọn ètò míràn, pínpín àwọn tí wọ́n ń wọ gbogbo orílẹ̀-èdè Europe, gẹ́gẹ́ bi aṣe é ṣe orílẹ̀-èdè kọ̀ọ̀kan.

column1: I mean, if you look at the relocation program that was approved by the Commission, always too little too late, or by the Council, too little too late --
column2: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, tí ẹ bá wo ètò ìṣípòpadà tí Àjọ náà fọwọ́sí, ó ń kéré jù ó ń pẹ́ jù ní gbogbo ìgbà, tàbí látọ́dọ̀ Àjọ náà, ó ń kéré jù ó ń pẹ́ jù.

column1: BG: It's already breaking down.
column2: BG: Ó ti ń dẹnukọlẹ̀.

column1: AG: My country is supposed to receive four thousand.
column2: AG: ó yẹ kí orílẹ̀-èdè mi gba ẹgbẹ̀rún merin.

column1: Four thousand in Portugal means nothing.
column2: Ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́rin ní orílẹ̀-ède Portugal ò túmọ̀ sí nǹkankan.

column1: So this is perfectly manageable if it is managed, but in the present circumstances, the pressure is at the point of entry, and then, as people move in this chaotic way through the Balkans, then they come to Germany, Sweden, basically, and Austria.
column2: Èyí ṣe é mójútó dáadáa tí wọ́n bá mójúto, ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú nǹkan tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ lọ́wọ́, ọ̀nà àbáwọlé ni ìṣòro wà, lẹ́yìn náà, bí àwọn ènìyàn ṣe ń rìn lọ́nà ìdàrúdápọ̀ sí Balkan, tí wọ́n sì wá sí orílẹ̀-ède Germany, Sweden, ní pàtàkì jùlọ, àti Austria.

column1: They are the three countries that are, in the end, receiving the refugees.
column2: Àwọn ni orílẹ̀-èdè mẹ́ta tí, nígbẹ́yìn, wón ń gba àwọn atìpó náà.

column1: The rest of Europe is looking without doing much.
column2: Àwọn ará ilẹ̀ Europe tókù ń wò láìṣe nǹkankan.

column1: BG: Let me try to bring up three questions, playing a bit devil's advocate.
column2: BG: e jẹ́ kí n bèrè ìbéèrè mẹ́ta, kí ń ṣe ìṣe alátakò.

column1: I'll try to ask them, make them blunt.
column2: Màá gbìyànjú láti bère wọn, láti sọ ojú abẹ níkò.

column1: But I think the questions are very present in the minds of many people in Europe right now, the first, of course, is about numbers.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n mo rò wí pé àwọn ìbéèrè náà wà ní ọkàn ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn nílẹ̀ Europe lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ báyìí, àkọ́kọ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, nípa iye wọn.

column1: You say 550 million versus one million is not much, but realistically, how many people can Europe take?
column2: Ẹ ní ọ̀tà-dín-léwà-dín-lẹ́gbẹ̀ta kojú ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún kan ti pọ̀jù, ṣùgbọ́n lóòótọ́, ènìyàn mélòó ni ilẹ̀ Europe lè gbà?

column1: AG: Well, that is a question that has no answer, because refugees have the right to be protected.
column2: AG: Ó dára, ìbéèrè tí ò ní ìdáhùn nìyẹn, nítorí àwọn atìpó ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí ìdáààbòbò.

column1: And there is such a thing as international law, so there is no way you can say, "I take 10,000 and that's finished.
column2: Nǹkan tó jọ bí òfin ilẹ̀ òkèré wà, nítorí náà kò sí ọ̀nà tí ẹ lè fi sọ wí pé, “Mo mú ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́wà ìyen sì ti tán.

column1: " I remind you of one thing: in Turkey, at the beginning of the crisis, I remember one minister saying, "Turkey will be able to receive up to 100,000 people.
column2: “ Mo rán-an yín létí nǹkankan: ní orílẹ̀-ède Turkey, ní ìbẹ̀rẹ rògbòdìyàn náà, mo rántí alákòso kan tó ń sọ wí pé, “orílẹ̀-ède Turkey máa lè gbà tó ẹgbẹ̀rún lónà ọgọ́rùn ènìyàn.

column1: " Turkey has now two million three-hundred thousand or something of the sort, if you count all refugees.
column2: “ Orílẹ̀-ède Turkey ti ní ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́ta àti ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọ̀rìn-dín-nírinwó tàbí nǹkan tó jọ bẹ́ẹ̀, tí ẹ bá ka gbogbo àwọn atìpó náà.

column1: So I don't think it's fair to say how many we can take.
column2: Torí náà mí ò rò wí pé ó bójúmu láti sọ wí pé mélòó ni a lè gbà.

column1: What it is fair to say is: how we can we organize ourselves to assume our international responsibilities?
column2: Nǹkan tó bójúmu láti sọ ni wí pé: báwo la ṣelè ṣèto arawa láti gba ojúṣe ilẹ̀-òkère wa?

column1: And Europe has not been able to do so, because basically, Europe is divided because there is no solidarity in the European project.
column2: Ilẹ̀ Europe kò tíì rí ìyẹn ṣe, nítorí ní pàtàkì, ilẹ̀ Europe ti pín nítorí kò sí ìṣọ̀kan nínú iṣẹ́-àkàṣe ilẹ̀ Europe.

column1: And it's not only about refugees; there are many other areas.
column2: Kì í ṣe nípa àwọn atìpó nìkan; àwọn àyè míràn tún wà.

column1: And let's be honest, this is the moment in which we need more Europe instead of less Europe.
column2: Ẹ jẹ́ ká sọ òdodo, àsìkò náà rè é tó ṣe wí pé a nílò ọ̀pọ Europe yàtọ̀ sí díẹ̀ Europe.

column1: But as the public less and less believes in European institutions, it is also each time more difficult to convince the public that we need more Europe to solve these problems.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n bí àwọn ará ìlú ṣe ń ní ìgbàgbọ́ tó kéré nínú àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ilẹ Europe, ní àsìkò kọ̀ọ̀kan yìí náà ló máa ń nira láti yí àwọn ará-ìlú lọ́kàn padà pé a nílò ọ̀pọ ilẹ̀-europe láti yanjú àwọn ìṣòro wọ̀nyìí.

column1: BG: We seem to be at the point where the numbers turn into political shifts, particularly domestically.
column2: BG: Ó jọ bí ẹni wí pé a ti dé ibi tí nọ́ḿbà náà ti yí padà di àyípadà òṣèlú, pàápàá jùlọ lábẹ́lé.

column1: We saw it again this weekend in France, but we have seen it over and over in many countries: in Poland and in Denmark and in Switzerland and elsewhere, where the mood changes radically because of the numbers, although they are not very significant in absolute numbers.
column2: A tún rí i lópin ọ̀sẹ̀ yìí lórílẹ̀-ède France, ṣùgbọ́n a ti rí i láìmọye ìgbà ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè: ní Poland àti ní Denmark àti ní Switzerland àti ibòmíràn, níbi tí ìmúlára ti yípadà nítorí nọ́ḿbà, bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé wọn ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ṣe pàtàkì nínú gbogbo oǹkà.

column1: The Prime Minister of --
column2: Olórí ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba ti --

column1: AG: But, if I may, on these: I mean, what does a European see at home in a village where there are no migrants?
column2: AG: ṣùgbọ́n, tí mo bá lè, lórí àwọn wọ̀nyí: mò ń sọ nípa pé, kíni ọmọ ilẹ̀ Europe ń rí nílé ní abúlé níbi tí kò sí àwọn aṣíkiri?

column1: What a European sees is, on television, every single day, a few months ago, opening the news every single day, a crowd coming, uncontrolled, moving from border to border, and the images on television were of hundreds or thousands of people moving.
column2: Nǹkan tí ọmọ ilẹ̀ Europe ń rí ni, lórí ẹ̀rọ amóhùn-máwòrán, lójoojúmọ́, ní oṣù díẹ̀ sẹ́yìn, ṣíṣí ìròyìn ní ọjọ́ kọ̀ọ̀kan, àwọn èrò tó ń bọ̀, láì ní ìdarí, tí wọ́n ń lọ láti ibodè sí ibodè, àwọn àwòrán lórí ẹ̀rọ amóhùn-máwòrán jẹ́ ti àwọn ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń lọ.

column1: And the idea is that nobody is taking care of it -- this is happening without any kind of management.
column2: Èrò wa ni wí pé kò sí ẹni tó ń ṣe àmójútó rẹ̀ -- èyí ń ṣẹlẹ̀ láìsí àmójútó kankan.

column1: And so their idea was, "They are coming to my village.
column2: Nítorí náà èro wọn ni wí pé, “Wọ́n ń bọ̀ wá sí abúlé mi.

column1: " So there was this completely false idea that Europe was being invaded and our way of life is going to change, and everything will -- And the problem is that if this had been properly managed, if people had been properly received, welcomed, sheltered at point of entry, screened at point of entry, and the moved by plane to different European countries, this would not have scared people.
column2: “ Èro irọ́ pátápátá yìí wà wí pé wọ́n ń kógun ja ilẹ̀ Europe àti wí pé àṣa wa máa yí padà, gbogbo nǹkan náà ló máa rí bẹ́ẹ̀ -- ìṣòro náà ni wí pé tí wọ́n bá ti mójútó o dáadáa ni, tí wọ́n bá gba àlejò àwọn ènìyàn bó ṣe tọ́ ni, tí wọ́n gbà wọ́n, tí wọ́n fún wọn lórùlé ní enu àbáwọlé, tí wọ́n ṣe àyẹ̀wo wọn ní ẹnu àbáwọlé, tí wọ́n sì fi ọkọ̀ òfuurufú gbé wọn lọ sí oríṣiríṣi orílẹ̀-ède ilẹ̀ Europe, èyí ò bá ti má dẹ́rùba àwọn ènìyàn.

column1: But, unfortunately, we have a lot of people scared, just because Europe was not able to do the job properly.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n, ó ṣeni láànú, a dẹ́rùba ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn, nítorí ilẹ̀ Europe ò ní àǹfààní láti ṣiṣẹ́ náà bó ṣe yẹ.

column1: BG: But there are villages in Germany with 300 inhabitants and 1,000 refugees.
column2: BG: ṣùgbọ́n àwọn abúlé kan wà ní orílẹ̀-ède Germany pẹ̀lu ọ̀rìn-dín-nírinwó àwọn olùgbé àti ẹgbẹ̀rún kan àwọn ogúnléndé.

column1: So, what's your position?
column2: Nítorí náà, kíni ipò yín?

column1: How do you imagine these people reacting?
column2: Báwo lẹ ṣe rò wí pé àwọn ènìyàn yìí ṣe ń húwà?

column1: AG: If there would be a proper management of the situation and the proper distribution of people all over Europe, you would always have the percentage that I mentioned: one per each 2,000.
column2: AG: Tí àmójútó tó bójúmu bá wà fún ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà àti pínpín àwọn ènìyàn káàkiri ilẹ̀ Europe lónà tó bójúmu, e ó máa ní ìdá tí mo mẹ́nubà ní gbogbo ìgbà: ẹyọkan nínú ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì.

column1: It is because things are not properly managed that in the end we have situations that are totally impossible to live with, and of course if you have a village -- in Lebanon, there are many villages that have more Syrians than Lebanese; Lebanon has been living with that.
column2: Nítorí pé wọn ò ṣàmójútó nǹkan lónà tó yẹ nígbẹ́yìn lafi ní ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tí kò ṣe é ṣe láti gbé pẹ̀lú rárá, bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni tí ẹ bá ní abúlé kan -- ní orílẹ̀-ède Lebanon, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn abúlé ló wà tí wọ́n ní ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède Syria ju ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède Lebanon lọ; orílẹ̀-ède Lebanon ti ń gbé pẹ̀lú ìyẹn.

column1: I'm not asking for the same to happen in Europe, for all European villages to have more refugees than inhabitants.
column2: Mi ò sọ wí pé kí irú rẹ̀ ṣẹlẹ̀ ní ilẹ̀ Europe, fún gbogbo àwọn abúlé nílẹ̀ Europe láti ní atìpó ju àwọn olùgbé lọ.

column1: What I am asking is for Europe to do the job properly, and to be able to organize itself to receive people as other countries in the world were forced to do in the past.
column2: Nǹkan tí mò ń bèrè ni kí ilẹ̀ Europe ṣe iṣẹ́ náà bó ṣe tọ́, láti lè ṣe àtúntò ara rẹ̀ láti gba àwọn ènìyàn gẹ́gẹ́ bi wọ́n ṣe fipá mú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè míràn lágbàyé láti ṣe é sẹ́yìn.

column1: BG: So, if you look at the global situation not only at Europe --
column2: BG: nítorí náà, tí ẹ bá wo ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà lágbàyé tí kìí ṣe ilẹ̀ Europe nìkan --

column1: BG: Yes!
column2: BG: bẹ́ẹ̀ ni!

column1: BG: If you look at the global situation, so, not only at Europe, I know you can make a long list of countries that are not really stepping up, but I'm more interested in the other part -- is there somebody who's doing the right thing?
column2: BG: Tí ẹ bá wo ìṣẹ̀lẹ náà lágbàyé, nítorí, kìí ṣe ní ilẹ̀ Europe nìkan, mo mọ̀ wí pé ẹ lè ṣe àkójọpọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọn ò gbéra sọ, ṣùgbọ́n mo nífẹ̀ nínú apá kejì -- ǹjẹ́ ènìkán wà tó ń ṣe nǹkan tó yẹ?

column1: AG: Well, 86 percent of the refugees in the world are in the developing world.
column2: AG: Ó dára, ìdá 86 àwọn ogúnléndé tó wà lágbàyé ni wọ́n wà ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó ń dágbà sókè.

column1: And if you look at countries like Ethiopia -- Ethiopia has received more than 600,000 refugees.
column2: Bí ẹ bá wo àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè bi Ethiopia -- Ethiopia ti gba àwọn ogúnléndé tó ju ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà 600 lọ.

column1: All the borders in Ethiopia are open.
column2: Gbogbo ibodè Ethiopia ló wà ní ṣíṣí sílè.

column1: And they have, as a policy, they call the "people to people" policy that every refugee should be received.
column2: Wọ́n sì ní, gẹ́gẹ́ bi ìpinnu, tí wọ́n ń pè ní ìpinnu “ènìyàn sí ènìyàn” wí pé gbogbo ogúnléndé gbọ́dọ̀ di gbígbà wọlé.

column1: And they have South Sudanese, they have Sudanese, they have Somalis.
column2: Wọ́n sì ní àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède South Sudan, wọ́n ní àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède Sudan, wọ́n ní àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède Somalia.

column1: They have all the neighbors.
column2: Wọ́n ní gbogbo àwọn alájọgbé.

column1: They have Eritreans.
column2: Wọ́n ní àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède Eritrea.

column1: And, in general, African countries are extremely welcoming of refugees coming, and I would say that in the Middle East and in Asia, we have seen a tendency for borders to be open.
column2: Làpapọ̀, àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Adúláwò ń gba àwọn atìpó tó ń bọ̀ gidi gan-an, mà á sì sọ wí pé ní Àárín Gbùngbun Ìlà Oòrùn àti ní Asia, a ti rí aṣe é ṣe fún ibodè láti di ṣíṣí sílẹ̀.

column1: Now we see some problems with the Syrian situation, as the Syrian situation evolved into also a major security crisis, but the truth is that for a large period, all borders in the Middle East were open.
column2: Báyìí à rí àwọn ìṣòro kọ̀ọ̀kan pẹ̀lú ìṣẹ̀lẹ orílẹ̀-ède Syria, bí ìṣẹ̀lẹ orílẹ̀-ède Syria ṣe yípadà di rògbòdìyan ètò-ààbò ńlá, ṣùgbọ́n òótọ́ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé fún ìgbà pípẹ́, gbogbo ibodè tó wà ní Àárín Gbùngbun Ìlà Oòrùn wà ló wà ní ṣíṣí sílẹ̀.

column1: The truth is that for Afghans, the borders of Pakistan and Iran were open for, at the time, six million Afghans that came.
column2: Òtítọ́ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé fún àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède Afghan, àwọn ibóde Pakistan àti Iran wà ní ṣíṣí fún, ní gbogbo ìgbà, àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ mẹ́fà ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède Afghan tó bá wá.

column1: So I would say that even today, the trend in the developing world has been for borders to be open.
column2: Mà á sọ wí pé kódà lónìí, ìṣesí ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó ń dàgbàsókè ni láti jẹ́ kí àwọn ibodè wà ní ṣíṣí sílẹ̀.

column1: The trend in the developed world is for these questions to become more and more complex, especially when there is, in the public opinion, a mixture of discussions between refugee protections on one side and security questions -- in my opinion, misinterpreted -- on the other side.
column2: Ọ̀nà tuntun náà ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó ti dágbàsókè ni fún àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí láti túbọ̀ díjú síi, pàápàá jùlọ nígbà tí, ní ìpinnu àwọn ará ìlú, àdàpọ ìjírórò láàárín ààbò ogúnléndé ní apá kan àti àwọn ìbéèrè ààbò -- ní tèmi, àṣìtú ìmọ̀ -- ní apá kejì.

column1: BG: We'll come back to that too, but you mentioned the cutting of funding and the vouchers from the World Food Programme.

column1: And my deep belief is that it was not the refugee movement that triggered terrorism.
column2: Ìgbàgbọ́ mi tó jinlẹ̀ ni wí pé kìí ṣe ìṣíkiri àwọn ogúnléndé ni ó ṣe okùnfa ìgbésùmọ̀mí.

column1: I think, as I said, essentially terrorism in Europe is today a homegrown movement in relation to the global situation that we are facing, and what we need is exactly to prove these groups wrong, by welcoming and integrating effectively those that are coming from that part of the world.
column2: Mo lérò, gẹ́gẹ́ bí mo ṣe sọ, ní pátàkì jùlọ ìgbésùmọ̀mí ní ilẹ̀ Europe lónìí jẹ́ ìpolongo lábẹ́lé ní ìbátan pẹ̀lú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àgbáyé tí à ń kojú, nǹkan tí a sì nílò ni láti dójúti àwọn ẹgbẹ́ yìí, pẹ̀lú gbígbà wọ́n wọlé ká sì dà àwọn tí wọ́n ń bọ̀ láti apá orílẹ̀-ède yẹn pọ̀ dáadáa.

column1: And another thing that I believe is that to a large extent, what we are today paying for in Europe is the failures of integration models that didn't work in the '60s, in the '70s, in the '80s, in relation to big migration flows that took place at that time and generated what is today in many of the people, for instance, of the second generation of communities, a situation of feeling marginalized, having no jobs, having improper education, living in some of the neighborhoods that are not adequately provided by public infrastructure.
column2: Nǹkan mìíràn tí mo gbàgbọ́ wí pé lọ́nà tó pọ̀, nǹkan tí à ń jìya rẹ̀ nílẹ̀ Europe lónì ni ìkùnà láti ṣe àfibò àwòṣe tí kò ṣiṣẹ́ ní àwọn 60s, ní 70s, ní 80s, ní ìbátan pẹ̀lú ìyípadà àṣíkiri ńlá tó ṣẹlẹ̀ ní ìgbà yẹn tó di nǹkan tó dà lónìí nínú ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn, fún àpẹẹrẹ, nínú àwọn ìran kejì àwùjọ, níní ìmọ̀lára ìpatì, láìníṣẹ́, láìní ètò ẹ̀kọ́ tó yè koro, gbígbé ní àwọn àdúgbò tí wọn ò pèse ohun amáyédẹrùn gbogbogbò fún.

column1: And this kind of uneasiness, sometimes even anger, that exists in this second generation is largely due to the failure of integration policies, to the failure of what should have been a much stronger investment in creating the conditions for people to live together and respect each other.
column2: Irú ìnira yìí, nígbà míràn ìbínú, tó máa ń wà ní ìran kejì yìí máa ń jẹ́ nítorí ìkùnà láti ṣe àfibọ̀ ìpinnu, sí ìkùnà nǹkan tó ye kó jẹ́ ìdókòwò tó lágbára nínú ìpèsè àyè fún àwọn ènìyàn láti gbé papọ̀ kí wọ́n sì bọ̀wọ̀ fún ara wọn.

column1: For me it is clear.
column2: Ní tèmi ó hàn kedere.

column1: For me it is clear that all societies will be multiethnic, multicultural, multi-religious in the future.
column2: Ní tèmi ó hàn kedere pé gbogbo àwùjọ yóò di, oníran-púpọ̀, aláṣà-púpọ̀, ẹlẹ́sìnpúpọ̀ lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

column1: And Europe, to a large extent, failed in that investment in the past few decades.

column2: Ní kété tí àlàfo bá ti wà nínú ọgbà náà, wọ́n yóò padà, láti bá àwọn akẹgbẹ́ wọn sọ̀rọ̀ lójijì gbogbo wọ́n ki kọjá, báyìí a ní erin méjìlá ní òdì kejì ọgbà àwùjọ.

column1: And now you're really in trouble.
column2: Báyìí e ti wọ wàhálà.

column1: People keep trying to come up with new designs for electric fences.
column2: Àwọn ènìyàn túbọ̀ ń gbìyànjú láti wá àpẹrẹ tuntun fún ọgbà onínọ́.

column1: Well, these elephants don't think much of those either.
column2: Ó dáa, àwọn erin wọ̀nyí ò ronu púpọ̀ nípa àwọn wọ̀nyẹn pẹ̀lú.

column1: So rather than having these hard-line, straight, electric, really divisive migratory-blocking fences, there must be other ways to look at this challenge.
column2: Dípò níní àwọn ọgbà gbọọrọ, onínọ́, tó ń ṣe ìpínyà tó sì ń dénà ìṣíkiri, ọ̀na mìíràn gbọ́dọ̀ wà láti wo ìdojúkọ yìí.

column1: I'm much more interested in holistic and natural methods to keep elephants and people apart where necessary.
column2: Mo nífẹ̀ púpọ̀ sí ìlànà apapọ̀ àti àdámọ́ láti ya erin àti ènìyàn sọ́tọ̀ níbi tó bá yẹ.

column1: Simply talking to people, talking to rural pastoralists in northern Kenya who have so much knowledge about the bush, we discovered this story that they had that elephants would not feed on trees that had wild beehives in them.
column2: Bíbá àwọn ènìyàn sọ̀rọ̀, bíbá àwọn adaranjẹ̀ agbègbè ní àríwa orílẹ̀-ède Kenya tí wọ́n ní ìmọ̀ tó pọ̀ nípa ìgbẹ́ sọ̀rọ̀, a ṣàwárí ìtàn yìí tí wọ́n gbọ́ pé àwọn erin ò ní jẹ igi tí afárá-oyin bá wà nínú rẹ̀.

column1: Now this was an interesting story.
column2: Ìtàn tó panilẹ́rìn lèyìí.

column1: As the elephants were foraging on the tree, they would break branches and perhaps break open a wild beehive.
column2: Bí àwọn erin ṣe ń wá oúnjẹ kiri lára igi, wọ́n máa gé ẹ̀ka àti bóyá wọ́n á gé afárá oyin tó burú.

column1: And those bees would fly out of their natural nests and sting the elephants.
column2: Àwọn oyin yìí máa fò jáde kúrò nínú ilé àdámọ́ wọn wọn ó sì ta erin náà.

column1: Now if the elephants got stung, perhaps they would remember that this tree was dangerous and they wouldn't come back to that same site.
column2: Bí wọ́n bá ta erin náà, bóyá wọ́n máa ràntí pé igi yìí léwu wọn ò sì ní padà sí agbègbè yẹn mọ́.

column1: It seems impossible that they could be stung through their thick skin -- elephant skin is around two centimeters thick.
column2: Ó jọ bí ẹni wí pé kò ṣe é ṣe pé wọ́n lè tawọ́n níbi awọ wọn tó nípọ̀n -- awọ erin nípọn tó sẹ̀ntímítà méjì.

column1: But it seems that they sting them around the watery areas, around the eyes, behind the ears, in the mouth, up the trunk.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n ó dàbí eni pé wọ́n máa ń ta wọ́n ní àwọn àyè tó lómi, níbi ojú, lẹ́yìn eti, ní ẹnu, àti ní òke owójà wọn.

column1: You can imagine they would remember that very quickly.
column2: Ẹ lè wòye wí pé wọn máa rántí ìyẹn kíákíá.

column1: And it's not really one sting that they're scared of.
column2: Kìí ṣe títa ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo ló ń bàwọ́n lẹ́rù.

column1: African bees have a phenomenal ability: when they sting in one site, they release a pheromone that triggers the rest of the bees to come and sting the same site.
column2: Àwọn oyin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní ipa tóyátọ̀: tí wọ́n bá tá nǹkan ní àyè kan, wọn yóò tu kẹ́míkà tí yóò ṣe okùnfa kí àwọn oyin tókù wá ta nǹkan náà ní àyè kan náà.

column1: So it's not one beesting that they're scared of -- it's perhaps thousands of beestings, coming to sting in the same area -- that they're afraid of.
column2: Nítorí náà kìí ṣe títa oyin ló ń bà wọ́n lẹ́rù -- bóyá títa ẹgbẹ̀rún oyin, tí wọ́n ń bọ̀ wá ta á ní àyè kan náà -- ló ń bà wọ́n lẹ́rù.

column1: And of course, a good matriarch would always keep her young away from such a threat.
column2: Lóòótọ́, obìnrin olórí ilé tó dára yóò mú àwọn omọ rẹ̀ kúrò níbi irú ewu bẹ́ẹ̀.

column1: Young calves have much thinner skins, and it's potential that they could be stung through their thinner skins.
column2: Àwọn ọmọ erin máa ń ní awọ tó tírín díẹ̀, ó sì ṣe é ṣe pé kí wọ́n tawọ́n ní àwọn awọ tó tínrín yìí.

column1: So for my PhD, I had this unusual challenge of trying to work out how African elephants and African bees would interact, when the theory was that they wouldn't interact at all.
column2: Fún oyè òmọ̀wé mi, mo ní ìdojúkọ tó ṣọ̀wọ́n nínú ìgbìyànjú láti wá ọ̀nà àbáyọ sí bí àwọn erin nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti àwọn oyin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ṣe lè ní àjọṣepọ̀, nígbà tí tíọ́rì náà jẹ́ wí pé wọn ò lè ní àjọṣepọ̀ rárá.

column1: How was I going to study this?
column2: Báwo ni mo ṣe fẹ́ ṣẹ̀wádi èléyìí?

column1: Well, what I did was I took the sound of disturbed African honey bees, and I played it back to elephants resting under trees through a wireless speaker system, so I could understand how they would react as if there were wild bees in the area.
column2: Ó dáa, nǹkan tí mo ṣe ni pé mo mú ohùn àwọn oyin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó ń dàmú, mo wá pílé rẹ̀ padà fún àwọn erin tí wọ́n ń simi lábẹ́ igi nínú ẹ̀rọ-gbohùngbohùn tí ò ní wáyà, kín lè mọ bí wọn ó ṣe sẹ tó bá ṣe wí pé oyin tó burú bá wà ní agbègbè náà.

column1: And it turns out that they react quite dramatically to the sound of African wild bees.
column2: Àbájáde rè ni wí pé wọ́n húwà tó jọ bí eré sí ohùn àwọn oyin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó burú.

column1: Here we are, playing the bee sounds back to this amazing group of elephants.
column2: Àwa rè é, tí à ń pílè ohùn oyin padà fún ẹgbẹ́ àwọn oyin tí wọ́n yanilẹ́nu yìí.

column1: You can see the ears going up, going out, they're turning their heads from side to side, one elephant is flicking her trunk to try and smell.
column2: Ẹ rí bí etí wọn ṣe ń lọ sókè, tó ń jáde, tí wọ́n ń yí orí wọn láti apákan sí ìkejì, erin kan ń fi ọwọ́ja rẹ̀ láti gbìyànjú lati gbóòrún.

column1: There's another elephant that kicks one of calves on the ground to tell it to get up as if there is a threat.
column2: Erin mìíràn wà tó ń ta ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ọmọ rẹ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nípà láti sọ fún-un wí pé kó dìde bí ẹni pé ewú wà.

column1: And one elephant triggers a retreat, and soon the whole family of elephants are running after her across the savannah in a cloud of dust.
column2: Erin kan ń gbíyànjú láti sá sẹ́yìn, láìpẹ́ gbogbo ẹbí erin ti ń sá tẹ̀le fòna nínú ẹ̀ṣú eruku.

column1: (Sound of bees buzzing)
column2: (ohùn oyin tó ń kùn).

column1: (Sound of bees ends)
column2: (ohùn oyin ti parí).

column1: Now I've done this experiment many, many times, and the elephants almost always flee.
column2: Mo ti ṣe ìdánwò yìí láìmọye ìgbà, àwọn erin náà fẹ́rẹ̀ lè sálọ ní gbogbo ìgbà.

column1: Not only do they run away, but they dust themselves as they're running, as if to knock bees out of the air.
column2: Kìí ṣe pé wọ́n sálọ nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n máa ń gbọnra bí wọ́n ṣe ńsálọ, bí ẹni pé wọ́n ń gbọn oyin danù.

column1: And we placed infrasonic microphones around the elephants as we did these experiments.
column2: A gbé àwọn ẹ̀rọ agbohùn kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ sí ọrùn àwọn erin náà bí a ṣe ń ṣe àyẹ̀wò wọ̀nyí.

column1: And it turns out they're communicating to each other in infrasonic rumbles to warn each other of the threat of bees and to stay away from the area.
column2: Àbájáde rẹ̀ ni wí pé wọ́n ń bá ara wọn sọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìkùn kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ láti kira wọn nílọ̀ nípa ewu oyin àti jíjínà sí agbègbè náà.

column1: So these behavioral discoveries really helped us understand how elephants would react should they hear or see bee sounds.
column2: Àwọn àwárí ìṣesí wọ̀nyí rànwá lọ́wọ́ gan-an láti ní òye bí àwọn erin ṣe ń húwà tí wọ́n bá fi lè gbọ́ ohùn oyin.

column1: This led me to invent a novel design for a beehive fence, which we are now building around small, one-to-two-acre farms on the most vulnerable frontline areas of Africa where humans and elephants are competing for space.
column2: Èyí ló darí mi láti ṣẹ̀da ìṣelọ́jọ̀ ọgbà afárá oyin àkọ́kọ́ṣe, tí à ń kọ́ nísinyìí káàkiri àwọn saare ilẹ̀ kan sí méjì oko kékèèké, ní àwọn àyè tí wọ́n léwájú ìkángun-séwu nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ níbi tí àwọn ènìyàn àti erin ti ń jìjàgùdù fún àyè.

column1: These beehive fences are very, very simple.
column2: Àwọn ọgbà afárá oyin wọ̀nyí rọrùn gidi gaan.

column1: We use 12 beehives and 12 dummy hives to protect one acre of farmland.
column2: A lo afárá oyin méjílà àti ẹ̀da afárá oyin méjílà láti dáààbòbo saare ilẹ̀-oko kan.

column1: Now a dummy hive is simply a piece of plywood which we cut into squares, paint yellow and hang in between the hives.
column2: Báyìí igi pilaiwúdù kan tí a gé sí igun mẹ́rin ni ẹ̀da afárá oyin, tí a kùn ní àwọ ayìnrín tí a fi há sáàrín afárá-oyin náà.

column1: We're basically tricking the elephants into thinking there are more beehives than there really are.
column2: À ń tan àwọn erin náà láti rò wí pé ilé oyin pọ̀ níbẹ̀ ju bó ṣe yẹ lọ.

column1: And of course, it literally halves the cost of the fence.
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni, ó sọ iye owó ọgbà náà di àbọ̀.

column1: So there's a hive and a dummy hive and a beehive and now dummy hive, every 10 meters around the outside boundary.
column2: Afárá kan àti ẹ̀da afárá àti afárá-òyin àti ẹ̀da afárá ló wà, ní gbogbo mítà mẹ́wà yíká ààlà ìta.

column1: They're held up by posts with a shade roof to protect the bees, and they're interconnected with a simple piece of plain wire, which goes all the way around, connecting the hives.
column2: Àwọn igi ló gbé wọn dúró pẹ̀lú òrùle abòji láti dáààbòbo àwọn oyin, wọ́n sì sopọ̀ pẹ̀lú ògidi wáyà kékeré kan, tó lọ yíká, tó so àwọn afárá oyin náà papọ̀.

column1: So if an elephant tries to enter the farm, he will avoid the beehive at all cost, but he might try and push through between the hive and the dummy hive, causing all the beehives to swing as the wire hits his chest.
column2: Bí erin kan bá gbìyànjú láti wọ oko náà, yóò sá fún afárá oyin náà lọ́nà kọnà, ṣùgbọ́n ó lè gbìyànjú láti kọjá láàárín afárá oyin àti ẹ̀da afárá oyin náà, tí yóò mú kí àwọn ilé oyin náà ó sún bí wáyà náà bá ṣe ń ba àya rẹ̀.

column1: And as we know from our research work, this will cause the elephants to flee and run away -- and hopefully remember not to come back to that risky area.
column2: Bí a ṣe mọ̀ látara iṣẹ́ ìwádìí wa, èyí máa jẹ́ kí erin náà sá kó sì feré ge – pẹ̀lú ìrètí wí pé yóò rántí láti má padà wá sí agbègbe ewu yẹn.

column1: The bees swarm out of the hive, and they really scare the elephants away.
column2: Àwọn oyin náà máa ṣùrù jáde nínú afárá náà, wọ́n ó sì lé erin náà lọ.

column1: These beehive fences we're studying using things like camera traps to help us understand how elephants are responding to them at night time, which is when most of the crop raiding occurs.
column2: Àwọn ọgbà afárá oyin tí à ń ṣe ìwádìí rẹ̀ pẹ̀lu lílo àwọn nǹkan bíi pánpẹ́ ayàwòrán láti jẹ́ ká ní òye bí àwọn erin ṣe ń húwà sí wọn lálẹ́, tó jẹ́ àsìkò tí jíjẹ nǹkan ọ̀gbìn máa ń ṣẹlẹ̀ jù.

column1: And we found in our study farms that we're keeping up to 80 percent of elephants outside of the boundaries of these farms.
column2: A rí i nínú àwọn oko ìwádìí wa wí pé à ń lé tó ìdá ọgọ́rin erin síta ààlà àwọn oko wọ̀nyí.

column1: And the bees and the beehive fences are also pollinating the fields.
column2: Àwọn oyin àti ọgbà afárá oyin náà ń gbọn ìyẹ̀rin sóri ilẹ̀ náà.

column1: So we're having a great reduction both in elephant crop raids and a boost in yield through the pollination services that the bees are giving to the crops themselves.
column2: À ń ní àdínkù tó pọ̀ nínú ìjẹko erin àti àlékún nínú irè oko nípasẹ̀ iṣẹ́ gbíbọn ìyẹ̀rin tí àwọn oyin náà ń fún àwọn nǹkan ọ̀gbìn fúnra wọn.

column1: The strength of the beehive fences is really important -- the colonies have to be very strong.
column2: Agbára ọgbà afárá oyin náà ṣe pàtàkì gidi gan-an -- àwọn ilé náà ní láti lágbára gidi gan-an.

column1: So we're trying to help farmers grow pollinator-friendly crops to boost their hives, boost the strength of their bees and, of course, produce the most amazing honey.
column2: À ń gbìyànjú láti bá àwọn àgbẹ̀ gbin àwọn irè-oko tí wọ́n bá ìyẹ̀rin rẹ́ láti ṣàlékún agbára afárá wọn, lóòótọ́, pèse oyin tó dára jù.

column1: This honey is so valuable as an extra livelihood income for the farmers.
column2: Oyin yìí lówó lórí gidi gan-an gẹ́gẹ́ bi àfikún ìpawówọlé fún àwọn àgbẹ̀.

column1: It's a healthy alternative to sugar, and in our community, it's a very valuable present to give a mother-in-law, which makes it almost priceless.
column2: Arọ́pò tó dára ló jẹ́ fún ṣúgà, ní àwùjọ wa, ẹ̀bùn tó jọjú ló jẹ́ láti fún ìyá-ìyàwo wa, tó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ sọ ọ́ di nǹkan olówó iye-bíye.

column1: We now bottle up this honey, and we've called this wild beautiful honey Elephant-Friendly Honey.
column2: A ti ń pọn oyin yìí sínú ìgò, a sì ti pe oyin búburú tó rẹwà yìí ní Oyin Abérin Sọ̀rẹ́.

column1: It is a fun name, but it also attracts attention to our project and helps people understand what we're trying to do to save elephants.
column2: Orúkọ tó panilẹ́rìn ni, ṣùgbọ́n ó tún pe àkíyèsí sí iṣẹ́ àkànṣe wa ó dẹ̀ ń ran àwọn ènìyàn lọ́wọ́ láti ní òye nǹkan tí à ń gbìyànjú láti ṣe láti dóòla àwọn erin.

column1: We're working now with so many women in over 60 human-elephant conflict sites in 19 countries in Africa and Asia to build these beehive fences, working very, very closely with so many farmers but particularly now with women farmers, helping them to live better in harmony with elephants.
column2: À ń ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ pẹ̀lú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn obìnrin ní àwọn àyè rògbòdìyàn ènìyàn àti ẹranko tó lé ní ọgọ́ta ní orílẹ̀-èdè mọ́kàn-dín-lógún nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti Asia láti kọ́ àwọn ọgbà afárá oyin wọ̀nyí, à ń ṣiṣẹ́ papọ̀ pẹ̀lú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn agbẹ̀ ṣùgbọ́n ní pàápàah jùlọ báyìí pẹ̀lú àwọn àgbẹ̀ lóbìnrin, ríràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́ láti gbé ní ìrẹ́pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn erin.

column1: One of the things we're trying to do is develop a toolbox of options to live in better harmony with these massive pachyderms.
column2: Ọ̀kan nínú àwọn nǹkan tí à ń gbìyànjú láti ṣe ni láti pèse àpótí-irinṣẹ́ oní yíyàn kan láti túbọ̀ gbé ní ìrẹ́pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹranko ńlá wọ̀nyí.

column1: One of those issues is to try and get farmers, and women in particular, to think different about what they're planting inside their farms as well.
column2: Ọ̀kan nínú ìṣoro yẹn ni láti rí àwọn àgbẹ̀, ní pátàkì jùlọ àwọn obìnrin, láti ní ìrónú tó yátọ̀ nípa nǹkan tí wọ́n ń gbìn sínú oko wọn bákan náà.

column1: So we're looking at planting crops that elephants don't particularly want to eat, like chillies, ginger, Moringa, sunflowers.
column2: À ń wo ṣíṣe ọ̀gbin àwọn irè oko tí àwọn erin ní pàtàkì jùlọ ò fẹ́ jẹ, bíi ata, ata ilẹ̀, mọ̀ríńgà, àti òdòdó-oòrùn.

column1: And of course, the bees and the beehive fences love these crops too, because they have beautiful flowers.
column2: Lóòótọ́ ni, àwọn oyin àti àwọn ọgbà afárá oyin fẹ́ràn àwọn irè-oko wọ̀nyìí pẹ̀lú, nítorí pé wọ́n ní àwọn òdòdó tó rẹwà.

column1: One of these plants is a spiky plant called sisal -- you may know this here as jute.
column2: Ọ̀kan nínú àwọn nkan ọ̀gbìn wọ̀nyí jẹ́ àwọn nǹkan-ọ̀gbìn tó máa ń pọ̀ tí wọ́n ń pè ní sísun -- ẹ lè mọ èyí sí júútì níbí yìí.

column1: And this amazing plant can be stripped down and turned into a weaving product.
column2: Nǹkan ọ̀gbìn tó dára yìí lè di bíbọ́ sí hòhò ká sì yi padà sí èròja híhun.

column1: We're working with these amazing women now who live daily with the challenges of elephants to use this plant to weave into baskets to provide an alternative income for them.
column2: À ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn obìnrin tí wọ́n dára báyìí tí wọ́n ń gbé pẹ̀lú ìdojúkọ àwọn erin ẹ̀da afárá oyin jẹ́ láti lo àwọn nǹkan ọ̀gbìn yìí láti hun apẹ̀rẹ̀ láti pèse apààrọ̀ ìpawówọlé fún wọn.

column1: We've just started construction only three weeks ago on a women's enterprise center where we're going to be working with these women not only as expert beekeepers but as amazing basket weavers; they're going to be processing chili oils, sunflower oils, making lip balms and honey, and we're somewhere on our way to helping these participating farmers live with better eco-generating projects that live and work better with living with elephants.
column2: A ṣẹ̀ bẹ̀rè síní kọ́ ọ ní bíi ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́ta sẹ́yìn sí àyè ilé-iṣẹ́ àwọn obìnrin níbi tí a ó ti máa ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn obìnrin wọ̀nyí tí kìí ṣe gẹ́gẹ́ bi òjìni olùtọ́jú-oyin nìkan ṣùgbọ́n gẹ́gẹ́ bi oníṣẹ́ ọnà apẹ̀rẹ̀; wọn yóò ma pèse òróró ṣílì, òróró òdòdó-oòrùn, ṣíṣe ìpara ètè àti oyin, a wà níbìkan lójú ọ̀nà láti ran àwọn àgbẹ̀ tí wọ́n ń kópa wọ̀nyí lọ́wọ́ láti ní ìgbeayé tó dára pẹ̀lú àwọn iṣẹ́-àkànṣe tó ń pèsè ọjọ̀ tó dára tí yóò ma gbé tí yóó sì ma ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìgbépọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn erin.

column1: So whether it's matriarchs or mothers or researchers like myself, I do see more women coming to the forefront now to think differently and more boldly about the challenges that we face.
column2: Torí náà bóyá àwọn obìnrin olórí ilé ni tàbí àwọn abiyamọ tàbí àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí bíi tèmi, mo máa ń rí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn obìnrin tí wọ́n ń léwájú báyìí láti ronú lọ́nà ọ̀tọ̀ tí wọ́n sì ní ìgboyà si nípa àwọn ìdojúkọ tí à ń kojú.

column1: With more innovation, and perhaps with some more empathy towards each other, I do believe we can move from a state of conflict with elephants to true coexistence.
column2: Pẹ̀lú ìṣẹdá lọ́pọ̀, àti bóyá pẹ̀lú àánú fún arawa, mo nígbàgbọ́ pé a lẹ̀ sún láti rògbòdìyàn pẹ̀lú erin sí àjọgbépọ̀ tòótọ́.

column1: Thank you.
column2: Ẹ seun.

column1: Will automation take away all our jobs?
column2: Ǹjẹ́ àdáṣe lè gba gbogbo iṣẹ́ wa lọ?

column1: Here's a startling fact: in the 45 years since the introduction of the automated teller machine, those vending machines that dispense cash, the number of human bank tellers employed in the United States has roughly doubled, from about a quarter of a million to a half a million.
column2: Òdodo-ọ̀rọ̀ tó yanilẹ́nu rè é: ní bíi ọdún márùn-lé-lógójì látígbà tí wọ́n ti ṣàfihàn ẹ̀rọ tó ń pọwó, àwọn ẹ̀rọ tó máa ń pọwó jáde wọ̀nyí, iye àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń gbà láti máa kawó ní orílẹ̀-ède United State ti di ìlọ́po méjì, láti bí ìdá mẹ́rin ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún di ìdajì àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́.

column1: A quarter of a million in 1970 to about a half a million today, with 100,000 added since the year 2000.
column2: Ìdá 4 àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ ní ọdún 1970 sí bíi ìdajì ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún lónìí, pẹ̀lú àfikún ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn láti ọdún 2000.

column1: These facts, revealed in a recent book by Boston University economist James Bessen, raise an intriguing question: what are all those tellers doing, and why hasn't automation eliminated their employment by now?
column2: Àwọn òdodo wọ̀nyí, tí wọ́n yojú rẹ̀ síta nínú ìwe onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé ní fásitì Boston James Bassen, béèrè ìbéèrè t’ó bà mí lẹ́rù: kíni àwọn tí wọ́n ń sanwó wọ̀nyẹn ń ṣe, kí l’ó fà á tí ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ-àdáṣiṣẹ́ ò ṣe tíì gbaṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ wọn lásíkò yìí?

column1: If you think about it, many of the great inventions of the last 200 years were designed to replace human labor.
column2: Bí ẹ bá ronú nípa rẹ̀, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìṣẹ̀dá ńlá láti bíi igba odún sẹ́yìn ni wọ́n ṣe láti rọ́pò iṣẹ́ ọmọ ènìyàn.

column1: Tractors were developed to substitute mechanical power for human physical toil.
column2: A ṣẹ̀da ọkọ̀ katakata ìdáko láti fi agbára ẹ̀rọ rọ́pò làálàá agbára kíkan ọmọ ènìyàn.

column1: Assembly lines were engineered to replace inconsistent human handiwork with machine perfection.
column2: A ṣẹ̀da ibi-ìtọkọ̀-papọ̀ láti fi ìṣedéédéé ẹ̀rọ rọ́pò àìṣedéédéé iṣẹ́-ọwọ́ ọmọ ènìyàn.

column1: Computers were programmed to swap out error-prone, inconsistent human calculation with digital perfection.
column2: A kọ-èdè-ìṣiṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá láti pààrọ àṣìṣe, àìṣedéédéé ìṣirò ọmọ ènìyàn pẹ̀lú àìṣedéédéé ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá ìgbàlódé.

column1: These inventions have worked.
column2: Àwọn ọgbọ́n ìpilẹ̀ṣe wọ̀nyí ti ṣiṣẹ́.

column1: We no longer dig ditches by hand, pound tools out of wrought iron or do bookkeeping using actual books.
column2: A ò fi ọwọ́ gbẹ́ kótò mọ́, k’á lu irinṣẹ́ jáde látara akọ irin tàbí k’á fi àwọn ìwé gangan ṣe ìfìwépamọ́.

column1: And yet, the fraction of US adults employed in the labor market is higher now in 2016 than it was 125 years ago, in 1890, and it's risen in just about every decade in the intervening 125 years.
column2: Síbẹ̀, apá kan àwọn àgbàlagbà tí wọ́n ń gbà ní ọjà òṣìṣẹ́ ti ga báyìí ní ọdún 2016 ju bí ó ṣe wà ní ọdún márùn-ún-lé-lọ́gọ́fà sẹ́yìn, ní ọdún 1890, ó sì ń lékún ní gbogbo ẹ̀wá ọdún láàárín ọdún márùn-ún-lé-lọ́gọ́fà náà.

column1: This poses a paradox.
column2: Èyí ń ṣe àfihàn ajọ̀ró-ṣòótọ́.

column1: Our machines increasingly do our work for us.
column2: Àwọn ẹ̀rọ wa ń ṣe àlékún iṣẹ́ wa fún wà.

column1: Why doesn't this make our labor redundant and our skills obsolete?
column2: Kí ló dé tí èyí ò ṣe jẹ́ kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ó léélẹ̀ kí ìmọ́ṣe wa ó sì má wúlò mọ́?

column1: Why are there still so many jobs?
column2: Kí ló dé tí iṣẹ́ ṣì ṣe pọ̀?

column1: I'm going to try to answer that question tonight, and along the way, I'm going to tell you what this means for the future of work and the challenges that automation does and does not pose for our society.
column2: Mà á gbìyànjú láti dáhùn ìbéèrè yẹn lálẹ́ yìí, bí a bá ṣe ń ṣe èyí, màá sọ nǹkan tí èyí túmọ̀ sí fún ọjọ́-iwájú iṣẹ́ àti ìdojúkọ tí ìdáṣe ń ṣe àti àwọn tí kò sí fún àwùjọ wa.

column1: Why are there so many jobs?
column2: Kí ló dé tí iṣẹ́ ṣe pọ̀.

column1: There are actually two fundamental economic principles at stake.
column2: Ìlàna ọrọ̀-ajé tó ṣe pàtàkì méjì ló wà nínú ewu.

column1: One has to do with human genius and creativity.
column2: Ọ̀kan ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ọpọlọ ọmọ ènìyàn àti ọgbọ́n àtinúdá.

column1: The other has to do with human insatiability, or greed, if you like.
column2: Ìkejì níṣe pẹ̀lu àìláyo-ọkàn ọmọ ènìyàn, ọ̀kánjúà, tí ẹ bá fẹ́.

column1: I'm going to call the first of these the O-ring principle, and it determines the type of work that we do.
column2: Màá pe àkọ́kọ́ nínú àwọn yìí ní ìlàna òrùka-O, ó sì máa ń ṣe okùnfa irú iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe.

column1: The second principle is the never-get-enough principle, and it determines how many jobs there actually are.
column2: Ìlànà kejì ni ìlàna kòtó, ó sì máa ń ṣe okùnfa iye iṣẹ́ tó wà.

column1: Let's start with the O-ring.
column2: Ẹ jẹ́ ká bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú òrùka-O.

column1: ATMs, automated teller machines, had two countervailing effects on bank teller employment.
column2: Àwọn ATM, ẹ̀rọ tó ń dá pọwó, ní ipa alágbára méjì lára ìgbanisíṣẹ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ ilé-ìfowópamọ́ tí wọ́n ń fúni lówó.

column1: As you would expect, they replaced a lot of teller tasks.
column2: Bí ẹ ṣe ń retí rẹ̀, wọ́n rọ́pọ̀ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iṣẹ́ àwọn tí wọ́n ń fúni lówó.

column1: The number of tellers per branch fell by about a third.
column2: Iye àwọn tí wọ́n ń fúnni lówó ní ẹ̀ka kọ̀ọ̀kan dínkù pẹ̀lú ìdá mẹ́ta.

column1: But banks quickly discovered that it also was cheaper to open new branches, and the number of bank branches increased by about 40 percent in the same time period.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ilé-ìfowópamọ́ padà ri wí pé ó rọjú láti ṣí ẹ̀ka tuntun, iye ẹ̀ka ilé-ìfowópamọ́ lékún pẹ̀lú bíi ìdá ogójì ní àsìkò kan náà.

column1: The net result was more branches and more tellers.
column2: Èsì àpapọ̀ ni wí pé bí ẹ̀ka ṣe ń pọ̀ si ni àwọn tí wọ́n ń fúni lówó náà ń pọ̀ si.

column1: But those tellers were doing somewhat different work.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn tí wọ́n ń fúni lówó yìí ń ṣiṣẹ́ ọ̀tọ̀.

column1: As their routine, cash-handling tasks receded, they became less like checkout clerks and more like salespeople, forging relationships with customers, solving problems and introducing them to new products like credit cards, loans and investments: more tellers doing a more cognitively demanding job.
column2: Gẹ́gẹ́ bi ojúṣe wọn, iṣẹ́ gbígba-owó dínkù, wọn ò yàtọ̀ sí agbowó wọ́n sì jọ abánitajà, níní àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn oníbàráà, yíyanjú àwọn ìṣòro àti ṣíṣe àfihàn àwọn ohun-èlò ọ̀tun bíi ike-ìgbawó, owó-ìyá àti ìdókòwò: ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn afúni lówó tí wọ́n ń ṣe àwọn iṣẹ́ tó gba ọpọlọ.

column1: There's a general principle here.
column2: Ìlànà àpapọ̀ wà níbí.

column1: Most of the work that we do requires a multiplicity of skills, and brains and brawn, technical expertise and intuitive mastery, perspiration and inspiration in the words of Thomas Edison.
column2: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe ló gba ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe lọ́pọ̀, àti ọpọ̀lọ àti agbára, òjìni onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ àti ọpọlọ ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe, ìlàágùn àti ìmísí nínú ọ̀rọ Thomas Edison.

column1: In general, automating some subset of those tasks doesn't make the other ones unnecessary.
column2: Lápapọ̀, ìdáṣe àwọn àtúnpín sẹ́ẹ́tì àwọn iṣẹ́ wọ̀nyẹn ò ní sọ àwọn tókù di aláìṣe pàtàkì.

column1: In fact, it makes them more important.
column2: Ní tòótọ́, ó máa ń jẹ́ kí wọ́n ṣe pàtàkì si ni.

column1: It increases their economic value.
column2: Ó máa ń ṣe àfikún ìwúlò ọrọ̀-ajé wọn ni.

column1: Let me give you a stark example.
column2: Ẹ jẹ́ kín fún-un yín ní àpẹẹrẹ kan tó fojú hàn.

column1: In 1986, the space shuttle Challenger exploded and crashed back down to Earth less than two minutes after takeoff.
column2: Ní ọdún 1986, ọkọ̀ òfuurufú oníjà gbiná ó sì já padà sí ayé lẹ́yìn bí ìṣẹ́jú méjì tó gbéra.

column1: The cause of that crash, it turned out, was an inexpensive rubber O-ring in the booster rocket that had frozen on the launchpad the night before and failed catastrophically moments after takeoff.
column2: Nǹkan tó ṣokùnfa jíjá yẹn, àbájáde rẹ̀, jẹ́ rọ́bà òrùka-O tí kìí ràn nínú afún rọ́kẹ́tì lágbára tó ti dì sóri páádì-ìgbéra lálẹ́ẹ ó kọ̀la tó sì kọṣẹ́ lọ́nà tó léwu ní àsìkò díẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tó gbéra.

column1: In this multibillion dollar enterprise that simple rubber O-ring made the difference between mission success and the calamitous death of seven astronauts.
column2: Ní ilé-iṣẹ́ ọlọ́pọ̀ bílíọ̀nu dọ́là tí rọ́bà òrùka-O lásán ti ṣe ìyàtọ̀ láàárín iṣẹ́ tó yege àti àjálù ikú àwọn arédùmarè méje.

column1: An ingenious metaphor for this tragic setting is the O-ring production function, named by Harvard economist Michael Kremer after the Challenger disaster.
column2: Ojúlówó àfiwé ẹlẹ́lọ̀ọ́ fún ibùdó ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ burúkú yìí ni ojúṣe ìṣẹ̀da òrùka-O, tí onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé Michael Kremer fún lórúkọ lẹ́yìn àjálù burúkú àwọn oníja.

column1: The O-ring production function conceives of the work as a series of interlocking steps, links in a chain.
column2: Iṣẹ́ ìpèsè òrùka-O fa ìròrí iṣẹ́ náà gẹ́gẹ́ bí oríṣiríṣi ìgbésẹ̀ tó wọnú ara wọn, tí wọ́n sopọ̀ nínú okùn kan.

column1: Every one of those links must hold for the mission to succeed.
column2: Ìkọ̀ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìsopọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn gbọ́dọ̀ ṣẹlẹ̀ kí iṣẹ́ náà lè di àṣeyọrí.

column1: If any of them fails, the mission, or the product or the service, comes crashing down.
column2: Bí ìkànkan nínú wọn bá kúnà, iṣẹ́ náà, tàbí ohun-èlò tàbí iṣẹ́ náà, yóò já lulẹ̀.

column1: This precarious situation has a surprisingly positive implication, which is that improvements in the reliability of any one link in the chain increases the value of improving any of the other links.
column2: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ aṣe é ṣe yìí ní àpadàbọ̀ rere tó yani lẹ́nu, tó ṣe wí pé àtúnṣe nínú ìgbáralé ìkọ̀ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìsopọ̀ náà máa ṣe àfikún ìwúlò àtúnṣe ìkànkan àwọn ìsopọ̀ yókù.

column1: Concretely, if most of the links are brittle and prone to breakage, the fact that your link is not that reliable is not that important.
column2: Ní àrídìmú, tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìsopọ̀ náà bá le tí wọ́n sì lè kán, pàápàá pé ìsopọ̀ yín ò ṣé gbáralé ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ṣe pàtàkì.

column1: Probably something else will break anyway.
column2: Bóyá nǹkan mìíràn ló máa kán báyẹn.

column1: But as all the other links become robust and reliable, the importance of your link becomes more essential.
column2: S̀ùgbọ́n bí àwọn ìsopọ̀ tókù ṣe ń tóbi síi tí wọ́n sì ṣe é gbáralé, pàtàki ìsopọ̀ yín yóò túbọ̀ wúlò si.

column1: In the limit, everything depends upon it.
column2: Ní gbèdéke, gbogbo nǹkan ló gbára lé e.

column1: The reason the O-ring was critical to space shuttle Challenger is because everything else worked perfectly.
column2: Ìdí tí òrùka-O ṣe ṣe pàtàkì sí àwọn ọkọ̀ òfuurufú oníjà ni wí pé gbogbo nǹkan tókù ló ṣiṣẹ́ dáadáa.

column1: If the Challenger were kind of the space era equivalent of Microsoft Windows 2000 --the reliability of the O-ring wouldn't have mattered because the machine would have crashed.
column2: Bí àwọn oníjà náà bá jẹ́ adọ́gba pẹ̀lú Microsoft Window ọdún 2000 -- ìgbáralé òrùka-O ò ní kàn wọ́n nítorí ẹ̀rọ náà yóò ti já lulẹ̀.

column1: Here's the broader point.
column2: Kókó-ọ̀rọ̀ tó tún fẹjú rè é.

column1: In much of the work that we do, we are the O-rings.
column2: Nínú ọ̀pọ̀lọ pọ̀ iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe, àwa ni òrùka-O.

column1: Yes, ATMs could do certain cash-handling tasks faster and better than tellers, but that didn't make tellers superfluous.
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn ẹ̀rọ ATM lè yára ṣe àwọn iṣẹ́ ju àwọn tí wọ́n ń fún ni lówó lọ, ṣùgbọ́n ìyẹn ò sọ àwọn tí wọ́n ń fún ni lówó di aláìwúlò.

column1: It increased the importance of their problem-solving skills and their relationships with customers.
column2: Ó ń ṣe àfikún sí pàtàki ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe ìyanjú-ìṣòro wọn àti àjọṣepọ̀ wọn pẹ̀lú àwọn oníbàárà.

column1: The same principle applies if we're building a building, if we're diagnosing and caring for a patient, or if we are teaching a class to a roomful of high schoolers.
column2: Irú ìlànà bẹ́ẹ̀ la máa lò tí a bá ń kọ́ ilé kan, tí a bá ń ṣe àyẹ̀wò tí a sì ń ṣe ìtọ́jú àwọn aláìsàn, tàbí tí a bá ń kọ́ kílásì àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní ilé-ìwe girama tó kún dẹ́nu.

column1: As our tools improve, technology magnifies our leverage and increases the importance of our expertise and our judgment and our creativity.
column2: Bi irinṣẹ́ ṣe ń dàgbá sókè, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí ṣe àfikún agbára wa ó sì ti ṣe àfikún sí pàtàkì ìmọ̀-òjìni wa àti ìdájọ́ wa àti ọgbọ́n àtinúdá wa.

column1: And that brings me to the second principle: never get enough.
column2: Èyí ló mú mi lọ síbi ìlànà kejì: kòtó.

column1: You may be thinking, OK, O-ring, got it, that says the jobs that people do will be important.
column2: Ẹ lè máa rò wí pé, ó dára, òrùka-O, ó yémi, tó sọ wí pé àwọn iṣẹ́ tí àwọn ènìyàn ń ṣe máa ṣe pàtàkì.

column1: They can't be done by machines, but they still need to be done.
column2: Àwọn ẹ̀rọ ò lè ṣe wọ́n, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n ṣì gbọdọ̀ di ṣíṣe.

column1: But that doesn't tell me how many jobs there will need to be.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n ìyen ò sọ fún mi iye iṣẹ́ tí yóò wà.

column1: If you think about it, isn't it kind of self-evident that once we get sufficiently productive at something, we've basically worked our way out of a job?
column2: Tí ẹ bá ronú nípa ẹ̀, ṣé kò fojú hàn pé tí a bá ti rí nǹkan ṣe, a ti wá ọ̀nà wa jáde kúrò níbi iṣẹ́ yẹn?

column1: In 1900, 40 percent of all US employment was on farms.
column2: Ní ọdún 1900, ìdá ogójì gbogbo ìgbanisíṣẹ́ ní orílẹ̀-ède US jẹ́ lórí oko.

column1: Today, it's less than two percent.
column2: Lónì, ó ti dínkù ní ìdá méjì.

column1: Why are there so few farmers today?
column2: Kí ló dé tí àwọn àgbẹ́ ṣe kéré lónì?

column1: It's not because we're eating less.
column2: Kìí ṣe nítorí pé a ò jẹun púpọ̀.

column1: A century of productivity growth in farming means that now, a couple of million farmers can feed a nation of 320 million.
column2: Òrún ọdún ìdàgbàsókè nínú iṣẹ́-àgbẹ̀ túmọ̀ sí wí pé ní báyìí, ìlọ́po ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn àgbẹ̀ lè bọ́ orílẹ̀-èdè tó ní ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún ọ̀rìn-dín-nírinwó lé lógún ènìyàn.

column1: That's amazing progress, but it also means there are only so many O-ring jobs left in farming.
column2: Ìtẹ̀síwájú tó yanilẹ́nu nìyẹn, ṣùgbọ́n ó tún túmọ̀ sí wí pé àwọn iṣẹ́ òrùka-O tó pọ̀ ló kù nínú iṣẹ́ àgbẹ̀.

column1: So clearly, technology can eliminate jobs.
column2: Ó fojú hàn kedere, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ lè pa iṣẹ́.

column1: Farming is only one example.
column2: Àpẹẹrẹ kan ṣoṣo ni iṣẹ́-àgbẹ̀ jẹ́.

column1: There are many others like it.
column2: Àwọn mìíràn bi irú rẹ̀ tún wà.

column1: But what's true about a single product or service or industry has never been true about the economy as a whole.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan tó jẹ́ òtítọ́ nípa ohun-èlò kan ṣoṣo tàbí iṣẹ́ tàbí ilé-iṣẹ́ kò fìgbà kan jẹ́ òtítọ́ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé lápapọ̀.

column1: Many of the industries in which we now work -- health and medicine, finance and insurance, electronics and computing -- were tiny or barely existent a century ago.
column2: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ tí a ti ń ṣisẹ́ báyìí -- ìlera àti òògùn, ìṣúná àti ìdójútófò, ohun-èlò tó ń loná àti ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá -- kéré tàbí wọn ò fẹ́rẹ̀ sí rárá bí ọ̀rún ọdún sẹ́yìn.

column1: Many of the products that we spend a lot of our money on -- air conditioners, sport utility vehicles, computers and mobile devices -- were unattainably expensive, or just hadn't been invented a century ago.
column2: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ nínú àwọn èròjà tí à ń ná ọ̀pọ owó wa lé lórí -- ẹ̀rọ amúlétutù, àwọn ọkọ̀ ọ̀bọ̀kún ọlọ́yé, ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àti àwọn ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ -- gbówó lórí gidi gan-an, tàbí wọn ò tíì ṣẹ̀da wọn bí ọrún ọdún sẹ́yìn.

column1: As automation frees our time, increases the scope of what is possible, we invent new products, new ideas, new services that command our attention, occupy our time and spur consumption.
column2: Bí àdáṣe ṣe ń ṣe ìtúsílẹ̀ àsìkò wa, tó ń ṣe àlékún ojú-ìwòye nǹkan tó ṣe é ṣe, a ṣẹ̀dá àwọn èròjà tuntun, èrò tuntun, iṣẹ́ tuntun t’ó ń pàṣẹ fún àkíyèsi wa, t’ó ń gba àkókò àti ìlo wa.

column1: You may think some of these things are frivolous -- extreme yoga, adventure tourism, Pokémon GO -- and I might agree with you.
column2: Ẹ lè rò bóyá àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí jẹ́ ìná àpà -- ìpẹ̀kun yóga, ìrìn-àjo afẹ́, Pokémon GO -- mo sì lè gbà pẹ̀lú yín.

column1: But people desire these things, and they're willing to work hard for them.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ènìyàn nífẹ̀ sí àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí, wọ́n sì ṣetán láti ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára fún wọn.

column1: The average worker in 2015 wanting to attain the average living standard in 1915 could do so by working just 17 weeks a year, one third of the time.
column2: Àròpin àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ní ọdún 2015 tí wọ́n dúró láti dé ipò àròpin ìgbeayé àwòkọ́ṣe ní ọdún 1915 lè ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe iṣẹ́ fún ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́tà-dín-lógún péré nínú ọdún kan, ìdá mẹ́ta àsìkò náà.

column1: But most people don't choose to do that.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn kìí fẹ́ ṣe ìyẹn.

column1: They are willing to work hard to harvest the technological bounty that is available to them.
column2: Wọ́n ṣetán láti ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára láti kórè ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ lọ́pọ̀ bó ṣe wà fún wọn.

column1: Material abundance has never eliminated perceived scarcity.
column2: Wíwà lọ́pọ̀ àwọn ohun-èlò kò tíì pa ọ̀wọ́n ti a kẹ́fín.

column1: In the words of economist Thorstein Veblen, invention is the mother of necessity.
column2: Nínú ọ̀rọ̀ onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé Thorstein Veblen, ìṣẹ̀dá ni ìyá fún kò ṣe é má nì.

column1: Now. So if you accept these two principles, the O-ring principle and the never-get-enough principle, then you agree with me.
column2: Nítorí náà tí ẹ bá gba àwọn ìlànà méjì wọ̀nyí, ìlàna òrùka-O àti ìlàna kòtó, ẹ ó gbà pẹ̀lú mi nígbà náà.

column1: There will be jobs.
column2: Iṣẹ́ yóò wà.

column1: Does that mean there's nothing to worry about?
column2: Ṣé ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí wí pé kò sí nǹkankan láti bẹ̀rù?

column1: Automation, employment, robots and jobs -- it'll all take care of itself?
column2: Ìdáṣe, ìgbanisíṣẹ́, ṣìgìdì-òyìnbó àti iṣẹ́ -- gbogbo wọn máa mójútó ara wọn?

column1: That is not my argument.
column2: Kì í ṣe àríyànjiyàn mi nìyẹn.

column1: Automation creates wealth by allowing us to do more work in less time.
column2: Ìdáṣe ń pèse ọrọ̀ pẹ̀lú fífún wa ní àǹfààní láti ṣiṣẹ́ tó pọ̀ ní àkókò péréte.

column1: There is no economic law that says that we will use that wealth well, and that is worth worrying about.
column2: Kò sí òfin ọrọ̀-ajé tó sọ wí pé a máa lo ọrọ̀ yẹn dáadáa, ìyen sì tó nǹkan tó yẹ ká ronú nípa rẹ̀.

column1: Consider two countries, Norway and Saudi Arabia.
column2: Ẹ wo orílẹ̀-èdè méjì, Norway àti Saudi Arabia.

column1: Both oil-rich nations, it's like they have money spurting out of a hole in the ground.
column2: Àwọn méjèèjì ni wọ́n ní epo, ó dà bí ẹni pé wọ́n ní owó tó ń jáde láti inú ihò kan nínú ilẹ̀ ni.

column1: But they haven't used that wealth equally well to foster human prosperity, human prospering.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n wọn ò lo ọrọ̀ náà dọ́gba dáadáa láti ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún àṣeyọrí ọmọ ènìyàn, àwọn ènìyàn tó ń ṣàṣeyọrí.

column1: Norway is a thriving democracy.
column2: Norway jẹ́ òṣèlú àwarawa tó ń dágbà.

column1: By and large, its citizens work and play well together.
column2: Lápapọ̀, àwọn ọmọ-ilú rẹ̀ ń ṣe iṣẹ́ àti eré papọ̀.

column1: It's typically numbered between first and fourth in rankings of national happiness.
column2: Ó wà láàárín ipò àkọ́kọ́ sí ìkẹ́rin ní àtò ìdùnú orílẹ̀-èdè.

column1: Saudi Arabia is an absolute monarchy in which many citizens lack a path for personal advancement.
column2: Saudi Arabia jẹ́ ilú ọlọ́ba tí àwọn ọmọ-ìlú rẹ̀ ò ní ònà sí ìtẹ̀síwájú araẹni.

column1: It's typically ranked 35th among nations in happiness, which is low for such a wealthy nation.
column2: Ó wà nípò karùn-lé-lọ́gbọ̀n nínú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n wà nínú ìdùnnú, tí ó kéré fún irú orílẹ̀-èdè tó lọ́rọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀.

column1: Just by way of comparison, the US is typically ranked around 12th or 13th.
column2: Pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe àfiwé lásán, orílẹ̀ ède US wà nípò kejìlá tàbí ìkẹtàlá.

column1: The difference between these two countries is not their wealth and it's not their technology.
column2: Ìyàtọ̀ tó wà láàárín àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè méjì yìí kì í ṣe ọrọ̀ wọn kì í sì í ṣe ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wọn.

column1: It's their institutions.
column2: Àwọn ilé iṣẹ́ wọn ni.

column1: Norway has invested to build a society with opportunity and economic mobility.
column2: Norway ti dókòwò láti kọ́ àwùjọ tó ní àǹfààní àti àgbékiri ọrọ̀-ajé.

column1: Saudi Arabia has raised living standards while frustrating many other human strivings.
column2: Saudi Arabia ti ṣe àfikún sí afiṣòdiwọ̀n ìgbeayé nígba tí wọ́n ń wàhálà ọ̀pọ̀ ìgbìyànjú àwọn ènìyàn mìíràn.

column1: Two countries, both wealthy, not equally well off.
column2: Orílẹ̀-èdè méjì, tí wọ́n lọ́rọ̀, tí ọrọ̀ wọn ò dọ́gba.

column1: And this brings me to the challenge that we face today, the challenge that automation poses for us.
column2: Èyí ló mú mi wá síbi ìdojúkọ tí à ń kojú lónì, ìdojúkọ tí àdáṣe ń ṣe fún wa.

column1: The challenge is not that we're running out of work.
column2: Ìdojúkọ náà kìí ṣe wí pé kò sí iṣẹ́.

column1: The US has added 14 million jobs since the depths of the Great Recession.
column2: Orílẹ̀-ède US tí ṣe àfikún àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ mẹ́rìnlá iṣẹ́ láti ìgbà òpin òjòjo ọrọ̀-ajé tó lágbára.

column1: The challenge is that many of those jobs are not good jobs, and many citizens cannot qualify for the good jobs that are being created.
column2: Ìdojúkọ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn iṣẹ́ wọ̀nyẹn kìí ṣe iṣẹ́ rere, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ará ìlú ò sì peregedé fún iṣẹ́ gidi tí wọ́n pésè.

column1: Employment growth in the United States and in much of the developed world looks something like a barbell with increasing poundage on either end of the bar.
column2: Ìdàgbàsókè ìgbanisíṣẹ́ ní orílẹ̀-ède United States àti ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn orílẹ́ èdè tí wọ́n ti gòkè àgbà dà bi irin tí wọ́n ń ṣe àfikún ìgbérin ní ìpẹ̀kun irin méjééjì.

column1: On the one hand, you have high-education, high-wage jobs like doctors and nurses, programmers and engineers, marketing and sales managers.
column2: Ní apá kan, ẹ ní ẹ̀kọ́ gíga, àwọn iṣẹ́ tí owó-iṣẹ́ wọ́n ga bíi oníṣégùn òyìnbó àti àwọn olùtọ́-ilé-ìwòsàn, àwọn onímọ̀ nípa kọ̀mpúta àti àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ, ìtajà àti àwọn alámòjútó ìtajà.

column1: Employment is robust in these jobs, employment growth.
column2: Ìgbanisíṣẹ́ pọ̀ nínú àwọn iṣẹ́ yìí, ìdàgbàsókè ìgbanisíṣẹ́.

column1: Similarly, employment growth is robust in many low-skill, low-education jobs like food service, cleaning, security, home health aids.
column2: Bákan náà, ìdàgbàsókè ìgbanisíṣẹ́ pọ̀ nínú àwọn iṣẹ́ oní ìmọ́ọ́ṣe-kékeré, àti ẹ̀kọ́ kékeré bíi iṣẹ́ oúnjẹ, agbálẹ̀, elétò ààbò, ìralnwọ́ ìlera inú-ilé.

column1: Simultaneously, employment is shrinking in many middle-education, middle-wage, middle-class jobs, like blue-collar production and operative positions and white-collar clerical and sales positions.
column2: Lásíkò kan náà, ìgbanisíṣẹ́ ń rù ní ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ẹ̀kọ́ tó wà lágbede méjì, owó-iṣẹ́ agbedeméjì, àwọn iṣẹ́-agbedeméjì, bi ìṣiṣẹ́ amojú-ẹ̀rọ àti iṣẹ́ alákọ̀wé àti ìtajà.

column1: The reasons behind this contracting middle are not mysterious.
column2: Ìdí tí àárín yìí fi ń há yìí kìí ṣémò.

column1: Many of those middle-skill jobs use well-understood rules and procedures that can increasingly be codified in software and executed by computers.
column2: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn iṣẹ́ ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe agbedeméjì máa ń lo àwọn òfin àti ìlànà tí ó yéni yéké tí wọ́n lè gbé sínú ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn tí wọ́n lè lò lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá.

column1: The challenge that this phenomenon creates, what economists call employment polarization, is that it knocks out rungs in the economic ladder, shrinks the size of the middle class and threatens to make us a more stratified society.
column2: Ìdojúkọ tí nǹkan yìí ń dásílẹ̀, nǹkan tí àwọn onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé ń pè ní ìpín sí méjì ìgbanisíṣẹ́, ni wí pé ó máa ń já àwọn àkàsọ nínú àkàba ọrọ̀-ajé, ó máa n jóro ìwọn àwọn tí wọ́n wà lágbedeméjì ó sì ń dúkokò láti sọ àwùjọ wa di onípele.

column1: On the one hand, a set of highly paid, highly educated professionals doing interesting work, on the other, a large number of citizens in low-paid jobs whose primary responsibility is to see to the comfort and health of the affluent.
column2: Ní apá kan, ọ̀wọ́ àwọn tí wọ́n ń gbowó geere, àwọn akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ tí wọ́n kàwé tí wọ́n ń ṣe iṣẹ́ tó rọrùn, lápá kejì, ogunlọ́gbọ̀n àwọn ará-ìlú tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ tí owó iṣẹ́ wọn kéré tí ojúṣe wọn gangan jẹ́ láti rí sí ìdẹ̀rùn àti ìlèra àwọn ọlọ́rọ̀.

column1: That is not my vision of progress, and I doubt that it is yours.
column2: Èyí kìí ṣe àfojúsùn ìlọsíwájú mi, mo sì ń ṣeyè méjì pé tiyín nìyẹn.

column1: But here is some encouraging news.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ìròyìn tó wúnilórí nìyí.

column1: We have faced equally momentous economic transformations in the past, and we have come through them successfully.
column2: A ti kojú àwọn àsìkò àyípadà ọrọ̀-ajé sẹ́yìn, a sì ti rí ọ̀nà àbáyọ kúrò nínú wọn láṣeyọrí.

column1: In the late 1800s and early 1900s, when automation was eliminating vast numbers of agricultural jobs -- remember that tractor?-- the farm states faced a threat of mass unemployment, a generation of youth no longer needed on the farm but not prepared for industry.
column2: Ní ìpẹ̀kun àsìkò 1800 àti ìbẹ̀rẹ àsìko 1900, nígbà tí ìdáṣiṣẹ́ ń pa ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn iṣẹ́ àgbẹ̀ -- ẹ rántí ọkọ̀-katakata-ìdáko? ipò àwọn oko náa kojú ewu aìníṣẹ́lọ́wọ́ tó pọ̀, ìran àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí a ò nílò lórí oko ṣùgbọ́n tí wọn ò ṣetán fún ilé-iṣẹ́.

column1: Rising to this challenge, they took the radical step of requiring that their entire youth population remain in school and continue their education to the ripe old age of 16.
column2: Kíkojú àwọn ìdojúkọ yìí, wọ́n gbé ìgbésẹ̀ akin fún pípè fún gbogbo àwọn ọ̀dọ́ láti dúró sí ilé-ẹ́kọ kí wọ́n sì tẹ̀sìwájú ẹ̀kọ wọn títí tí wọn ó fi bàlágà di ọmọ ọdún mẹ́rìn-dín-lógún.

column1: This was called the high school movement, and it was a radically expensive thing to do.
column2: Èyí ni wọ́n pè ní ìtẹ̀síwájú ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga, ó sì jẹ́ nkan tó wọ́n láti ṣe.

column1: Not only did they have to invest in the schools, but those kids couldn't work at their jobs.
column2: Kìí ṣe pé wọ́n ní láti dókòwò nínú àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ọmọ wọ̀nyẹn ò lè ṣe iṣẹ́ wọn.

column1: It also turned out to be one of the best investments the US made in the 20th century.
column2: Ó padà di ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìdókòwò t’ó dára jù tí orílẹ̀-ède US ti ṣe ní ọ̀rún ọdún ogún.

column1: It gave us the most skilled, the most flexible and the most productive workforce in the world.
column2: Ó fún wa ní ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe tó pọ̀ jù, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ tí wọ́n lè yípadà jù tí wọ́n sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ jù lágbàáyé.

column1: To see how well this worked, imagine taking the labor force of 1899 and bringing them into the present.
column2: Láti lè rí bí èyí ṣe ṣiṣẹ́ sí, ẹ wòye mímú àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ odún 1899 ká mú wọn wá sí àsìkò lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

column1: Despite their strong backs and good characters, many of them would lack the basic literacy and numeracy skills to do all but the most mundane jobs.
column2: Pẹ̀lú ẹ̀yìn líle àti ìwà rere wọn, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wọn ò ní ìmọ̀ ìpìlẹ̀ àti ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe ònkà láti ṣe gbogbo rẹ̀ ṣùgbọ́n àwọn iṣẹ́ tí ò múnú ẹni dùn.

column1: Many of them would be unemployable.
column2: Ọ̀pọ̀ nínú wọn ni ò ní ṣe é gbà síṣẹ́.

column1: What this example highlights is the primacy of our institutions, most especially our schools, in allowing us to reap the harvest of our technological prosperity.
column2: Nǹkan tí àpẹẹrẹ yìí tọ́ka sí ni pàtàkì àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ wa, pàápàá jùlọ àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ wa, láti gbàwá láyè láti kórè ìlọsíwájú ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wa.

column1: It's foolish to say there's nothing to worry about.
column2: Ìwà òpònú ni láti sọ wí pé kò sí nǹkankan láti bẹ̀rù.

column1: Clearly we can get this wrong.
