column2: Àbí ṣe ẹ rò ó rí, nígbà tí ẹ bá lọ kí ọ̀rẹ yín kan, nípa fífi oríkè díẹ̀ lára yín sílẹ̀ ní gbogbo àyè tí ẹ ti fọwọ́ kàn?

column1: And even this evening, have you paid any attention to sit without touching anything?
column2: Kódà lálẹ́ yìí, ǹjẹ́ ẹ ti ṣe àkíyèsí jíjókò láì fi ọwọ́ kan nǹkankan?

column1: Well, you're not alone.
column2: Ó dáa, ẹ ò dá wà.

column1: Thankfully, criminals underestimate the power of fingerprints, too.
column2: Ìkúnfúnọpẹ́, àwọn ọ̀daràn ń ṣàfojúdi agbára òntẹ̀-ìka, bákan náà.

column1: And I'm not just talking about the twisted parting of lines that make our fingerprint unique.
column2: Mi ò sọ̀ nípa àwọn ilà lílọ́pọ̀ tí wọ́n jẹ́ kí òntẹ̀-ìka wá yátọ̀ gédéngbé nìkan.

column1: I'm talking about an entire world of information hiding in a small, often invisible thing.
column2: Mò ń sọ nípa odidi àgbáramúramú ìfitóni t’ó sá pamọ́ sára nǹkan kékeré, tí ò ṣe é fojú rí lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà.

column1: In fact, fingerprints are made up of molecules that belong to three classes: sweat molecules that we all produce in very different amounts molecules that we introduce into our body and then we sweat out and molecules that we may contaminate our fingertips with when we come across substances like blood, paint, grease, but also invisible substances.
column2: Ní òótọ́, òntẹ̀-ìka jẹ́ àpapọ̀ àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tí wọ́n wà ní ẹ̀ka mẹ́ta: ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ àágùn tí à ń ṣẹ́ ní iye ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tó yátọ̀ tí à ń lò sínú ara wa tí a bá sì làágùn síta àti àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tí ó ń ṣàkóbá etí ọmọ-ìka wa tí a bá ṣe alábàpádè àwọn nǹkan bí ẹ̀jẹ̀, ọ̀dà, gírísì, àti àwọn nǹkan àìfojúrí.

column1: And molecules are the storytellers of who we are and what we've been up to.
column2: Ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ jẹ́ asọ̀tàn nípa irú ẹni tí à ń ṣe àti àti nǹkan tí a ti ṣe.

column1: We just need to have the right technology to make them talk.
column2: A kọ̀ nílò láti ní ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tó tọ́ láti jẹ́ kí wọ́n sọ̀rọ̀ ni.

column1: So let me take you on a journey of unthinkable capabilities.
column2: Ẹ jẹ́ kí n múu yín rin ìrìnàjò ìkápá aláìlérò kan.

column1: Katie has been raped and her lifeless body has been found in the woods three days later, after her disappearance.
column2: Wọ́n ti fipá bá Katie lájọṣepọ̀ wọ́n sì ti rí òku rẹ̀ nínú igbó, lẹ́yìn ọjọ́ mẹ́ta tí ó pòórá.

column1: The police is targeting three suspects, having narrowed down the search from over 20 men who had been seen in that area on the same day.
column2: Awọn ọlọ́pàá ń tọpa àwọn afurasí mẹ́ta, lẹ́yìn ìgbà tí wọ́n mú ìtọpa ìwádìí àwọn afurasí wọn wálẹ̀ láti 20 ọkùnrin tí wọ́n ti rí ní agbègbè náà lọ́jọ́ yẹn náà.

column1: The only piece of evidence is two very faint, overlapping fingerprints on the tape that was found wrapped around Katie's neck.
column2: Èrí kan ṣoṣo ni òntẹ̀-ìka méjì tí kò hàn rere, àgbélérawọn lórí àjábùlẹ̀ tí wọ́n wé mọ́ ọrùn Katie tí wọ́n rí.

column1: Often, faint and overlapping fingerprints cannot help the police to make an identification.
column2: Lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà, òntẹ̀-ìka tí kò hàn rere, t’ó wà lórí ara wọn kò lè ran àwọn ọlọ́pàá lọ́wọ́ láti ṣe ìdánimọ̀.

column1: And until recently, this might have been the end of the road, but this is where we can make the difference.
column2: Àfi láìpẹ́ yìí, èyí ò bá ti jẹ òpin ọ̀nà, ṣùgbọ́n ibí tí a ti lè ṣe àtúnṣe nìyí.

column1: The tape is sent to our labs, where we're asked to use our cutting-edge technology to help with the investigation.
column2: Wọ́n fi àjábùlẹ̀ náà ránṣẹ́ sí àyè fún ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ wa, níbi tí wọ́n ti ní k’á lo ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ aláìlẹ́gbẹ́ wa láti ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ fún ìtọpinpin náà.

column1: And here, we use an existing form of mass spectrometry imaging technology that we have further developed and adapted specifically for the molecular and imaging analysis of fingerprints.
column2: Níbí, a lo ẹ̀dà ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ àṣàwòrán ẹ̀rọ igbọ̀n agbọ̀n ńlá tó wà nílẹ̀ tí a ti ṣe ìdàgbàsókè rẹ̀ síwájú síi tí a ṣe ní àdáyanrí fún ìyànàna ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ àti àwòran òntẹ̀-ìka.

column1: In essence, we fire a UV laser at the print, and we cause the desorption of the molecules from the print, ready to be captured by the mass spectrometer.
column2: Ní pàtàkì, a bẹ́ná ìtànṣán UV sí òntẹ̀ náà, a sì mú kí ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ náà ó yọ kúrò lára òntẹ̀ náà, t’ó ti ṣe tán láti di yíya pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rọ òdiwọ̀n-ìbìlù àkópọ̀.

column1: Mass spectrometry measures the weight of the molecules -- or as we say, the mass -- and those numbers that you see there, they indicate that mass.
column2: Ẹ̀rọ òdiwọ̀n-ìbìlù àkópọ̀ máa dìwọ̀n ìwúwo ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ náà -- tàbí bí a ṣe sọ, ìwọn àkópọ̀ -- àti àwọn oǹkà tí ẹ̀ ń wò níbẹ̀ yẹn, wọ́n ń ṣàfihàn ìwọ̀n àkópọ̀ yẹn.

column1: But more crucially, they indicate who those molecules are -- whether I'm seeing paracetamol or something more sinister, forensically speaking.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n ní pàtàkì jùlọ, wọ́n ń ṣàfihàn ẹni tí àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wọ̀nyí jẹ́ -- bóyá mò ń rí paracetamol tàbí nǹkan tó tún léwu jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ, tí a bá ń sọ̀rọ̀ nílàna ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀.

column1: We applied this technology to the evidence that we have and we found the presence of condom lubricants.
column2: A sàmúlò ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ yìí sí èrí tí a ní a dè rí ìdúró ìmúdiyíyọ̀ rọ́bà ìdáààbòbò.

column1: In fact, we've developed protocols that enable us to even suggest what brand of condom might have been used.
column2: Lóòótọ́, a ti ṣe ìdàgbàsókè ìlànà-àátẹ̀lé tí yóò fún wa ní àǹfààní láti dábàá irú rọ́bà ìdáààbòbò tí wọ́n lò.

column1: So we pass this information to the police, who, meanwhile, have obtained a search warrant and they found the same brand of condom in Dalton's premises.
column2: A fi afitóni yìí ránṣẹ́ sí àwọn ọlọ́pàá, tí wọ́n, láímọ̀, ti gba àṣẹ láti túlé wọ́n sì ti rí irú rọ́bà idáààbòbò yìí kan náà ní àyíká ilé Dalton.

column1: And with Dalton and Thomson also having records for sexual assaults, then it is Chapman that may become the less likely suspect.
column2: Pẹ̀lú pé Dalton àti Thomson tún ní àkọsílẹ̀ ìfipábánilòpọ̀, a jẹ́ wí pé Chapman ló lè di ẹni tí a lè má furasí púpọ̀

column1: But is this information enough to make an arrest?
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n ṣe afitóni yìí tó láti fi àṣẹ ọba mú?

column1: Of course not, and we are asked to delve deeper with our investigation.
column2: Rárá, wọ́n sì sọ fún wa pé ká túṣu désálẹ̀ ìkòkò pẹ̀lú ìwádìí wa.

column1: So we found out, also, the presence of other two very interesting molecules.
column2: A ṣàwárí rẹ̀, bákan náà, ìdúró àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ méjì tó yanilẹ́nu.

column1: One is an antidepressant, and one is a very special molecule.
column2: Ọ̀kan jẹ́ apa-ìrẹ̀wẹ̀sì-ọkàn, ọ̀kan sì jẹ́ ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ molecule tó yátọ̀ gidi gan-an.

column1: It only forms in your body if you drink alcohol and consume cocaine at the same time.
column2: Ó máa ń dì sára nígbà tí ẹ bá mu ọtí tàbí lo oògùn-olóró lásíkò kan náà.

column1: And alcohol is known to potentiate the effects of cocaine, so here, we now have a hint on the state of mind of the individual whilst perpetrating the crime.
column2: A sì mọ ọtí pé ó máa ń ṣe ìrólágbára fún ipa oògùn-olóró, nítorí náà níbí, a ti ní afitóni nípa ipò ẹ̀mí ẹni náà nígbà t’ó ń hu ìwà ọ̀daràn náà.

column1: We passed this information to the police, and they found out that, actually, Thomson is a drug addict, and he also has a medical record for psychotic episodes, for which presumably the antidepressant was prescribed.
column2: A fi afitóni yìí ránṣẹ́ sí àwọn ọlọ́pàá, wọ́n ṣàwárí rẹ̀ pé, lóòótọ́, Thomson kúndùn oògùn-olóró, ó sì ní àkọsílẹ̀ ìwòsàn agàná, fún èyì tó ṣe wí pé bóyá torí rẹ̀ ni wọ́n ṣe ṣe àṣàyàn apa-ìrẹ̀wẹ̀sì-ọkàn.

column1: So now Thomson becomes the more likely suspect.
column2: Ní báyìí Thomson ti di afurasí tó ṣe é ṣe.

column1: But the reality is that I still don't know where these molecules are coming from, from which fingerprint, and who those two fingerprints belong to.
column2: Ṣùgbón òdodo ibẹ̀ ni wí pé mi ò tíì mọ ibi tí àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wọ̀nyí ti ń wá, láti òntẹ̀-ìka wo, àti eni tí àwọn òntẹ̀-ìka méjì yìí jẹ́ tirẹ̀.

column1: Fear not.
column2: Ẹ má bẹ́rù.

column1: Mass spectrometry imaging can help us further.
column2: Ẹ̀rọ igbọ̀n agbọ̀n ńlá lè ràn wá lọ́wọ́ síwájú síi.

column1: In fact, the technology is so powerful that we can see where these molecules are on a fingerprint.
column2: Lódodo, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ náà lágbára gidi gan-an débi wí pé a lè rí ibi tí àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wọ̀nyí wà lórí òntẹ̀-ìka.

column1: Like you see in this video, every single one of those peaks corresponds to a mass, every mass to a molecule, and we can interrogate the software, by selecting each of those molecules, as to where they are present on a fingermark.
column2: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹ ṣe rí i nínú fọ́rán yìí, ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan àwọn tí wọ́n gajù wọ̀nyẹn túmọ̀ sí ìwọ̀n-okun, ìwọ̀n-okun kọ̀ọ̀kan sí ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ kan, a sì lè fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn náà lẹ́nu wò, pẹ̀lú mímú ìkọ̀ọ̀kan àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn, nípa ibi tí wọ́n wà lórí àpá-ìka náà.

column1: And some images are not very revealing, some are better, some are really good.
column2: Àwọn àwòràn kan ò kí ń f’ara hàn dáadáa, àwọn kan dára, àwọn kan dára gidi gan-an.

column1: And we can create multiple images of the same mark -- in theory, hundreds of images of the same fingerprint -- for as many of the molecules that we have detected.
column2: A ṣẹ̀dá ọ̀pọ̀ àwòrán àpá kan náà -- ní tíọ́rì, ọgọ́rùn àwòran òntẹ̀-ìka kan náà -- fún gbogbo iye ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tí a ti rí.

column1: So step one for overlapping fingerprints, chances are, especially if they come from different individuals, that the molecular composition is not identical, so let's ask the software to visualize those unique molecules just present in one fingermark and not in the other one.
column2: Ìgbésẹ̀ àkọ́kọ́ fún òntẹ̀-ìka tó gorí ara wọn, àǹfààní ni pé, pàápàá jùlọ tí wọ́n bá wá látara oríṣiríṣi ènìyàn, pé ìṣẹ̀da ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ náà kò jọra wọn, nítorí náà ẹ jẹ́ k’á béèrè lọ́wọ́ ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn láti wo àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ aṣèyàtò tó wà nínú òntẹ̀-ìka kan tí ò sí ní ìkejì.

column1: By doing so, that's how we can separate the two ridge patterns.
column2: Pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, bí a ṣe lè ṣe ìyàsọ́tọ̀ bátánì etíi méjééjì nìyẹn.

column1: And this is really important because the police now are able to identify one of the two fingerprints, which actually corresponds to Katie.
column2: Èyí sì ṣe pàtàkì nítorí àwọn ọlọ́pàá lè tọ́ka sí ọ̀kan nínú òntẹ̀-ìka méjééjì báyìí, tó bá ti Katie mu.

column1: And they've been able to say so because they've compared the two separate images with one taken posthumously from Katie.
column2: Wọ́n ti lè sọ bẹ́ẹ̀ nítorí pé wọ́n ti fi àwòrá méjì ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ náà wéra wọn pẹ̀lú ìkan tí wọ́n mú látara òku Katie.

column1: So now, we can concentrate on one fingerprint only -- that of the killer's.
column2: Ní báyìí, a lè gbájúmọ́ òntẹ̀-ìka kan ṣoṣo -- tó jẹ́ ti aṣekúpani yẹn.

column1: So then, step two where are these three molecules that I've seen?
column2: Lẹ́yìn náà, ìgbésẹ̀ kejì àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ mẹ́ta wọ̀nyí tí mo ti rí yìí dà?

column1: Well, let's interrogate the software -- show me where they are.
column2: Ó dáa, ẹ jẹ́ k’á fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn náà lẹ́nu wò -- fi ibi tí wọ́n wà hàn mí.

column1: And by doing this, only portions of the image of the killer's fingerprint show up.
column2: Pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe èyí, apá kan àwòrán òntẹ̀-ìka aṣekúpani náà nìkan l’ó hàn.

column1: In other words, those substances are only present in the killer's print.
column2: Ìyẹn ni wí pé, àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyẹn wà nínú òntẹ̀ aṣekúpani náà nìkan ni.

column1: So now our molecular findings start matching very nicely the police intelligence about Thomson, should that fingerprint belong to him.
column2: Ní báyìí aṣàwárí ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wa bẹ́rẹ̀ síní bá ìwádìí àwọn olọ́pà nípa Thomson mu dáadáa, tí ó bá jẹ́ wí pé òun ló ni òntẹ̀-ìka yẹn.

column1: But the reality is that that print is still not good enough to make an identification.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n òtítọ́ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé ọ̀ntẹ̀ yẹn ò tíì dára tó láti ṣe ìdánímọ̀.

column1: Step three: since we can generate hundreds of images of the same fingerprint, why don't we superimpose them, and by doing so, try to improve the rich pattern of continuity and clarity?
column2: Ìgbésẹ̀ kẹ́ta: nígbà tó jé wí pé a lè ṣẹ̀da ọgọ́rùn àwòrán òntẹ̀ ìka kan náà, kí ló dé tí a ò gbé wọn sórí ara wọn, tí a bá ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, ká gbìyànjú láti ṣe àfikún bátánì ìtẹ̀síwájú àti ìfojúhàn tó kún?

column1: That's the result.
column2: Èsì náà nìyẹn.

column1: We now have a very clear image of the fingerprint and the police can run it through the database.
column2: A ti wá ní àwòrán òntẹ̀-ìka tó hàn kedere àwọn ọlọ́pàá sì le lò ó lórí àká-ìwífún-alálàyé.

column1: The match comes out to Thomson.
column2: Ìbámu náà jáde sí ti Thomson.

column1: Thomson is our killer.
column2: Thomson ni aṣekúpani wa.

column1: Katie, the suspects and the circumstances of the crime aren't real, but the story contains elements of the real police casework we've been confronted with, and is a composite of the intelligence that we can provide -- that we have been able to provide the police.
column2: Katie, afurasí náà àti àwọn nǹkan tó rọ̀ mọ́ ìwà-ọ̀daràn náà kìí ṣe tòótọ́, ṣùgbọ́n ìtàn náà ní àwọn ọmọlẹ̀ iṣẹ́-ìwádìí ọlọ́pàá tòótọ́ tí a ti kojú rẹ̀, ó sì jẹ́ ẹ̀ka ìwádìí tí a lè pèsè -- tí a ti pèsè fún àwọn olọ́pàá.

column1: And I'm really, really thrilled that after nine years of intense research, as of 2017, we are able to contribute to police investigations.
column2: Inú mi sì ń dùn gidi gan-an pé lẹ́yìn ọdún mẹ́sàn ìwádìí alágbára, ní ọdún 2017, a ní àǹfààní láti dásí ìtọpinpin àwọn ọlọ́pàá.

column1: Mine is no longer a dream; it's a goal.
column2: Tèmi kìí ṣe àlá mọ́; ìpinnu ni.

column1: We're going to do this wider and wider, bigger and bigger, and we're going to know more about the suspect, and we're going to build an identikit.
column2: A máa ṣe èyí ní fífẹ̀ àti fífẹ̀, ńlá àti ńlá, a sì ma nímọ̀ si nípa afurasí náà, a sì ma ṣẹ̀dá ẹ̀rọ-ìdánimọ̀.

column1: I believe this is also a new era for criminal profiling.
column2: Mo nígbàgbọ́ pé ìgbà ọ̀tun ni èyí fún ṣíṣe àkọsílẹ̀ ìwà-ọ̀daràn.

column1: The work of the criminologist draws on the expert recognition of behavioral patterns that have been observed before to belong to a certain type, to a certain profile.
column2: Iṣẹ́ ìwádìí ìwà ọ̀daràn máa ń lo ìdámọ̀ àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ nípa bátánì ìhùwàsí tí wọ́n ti ṣàkíyèsí tẹ́lẹ̀ pé ó jẹ́ ti ẹ̀yà kan, sí àkọsílẹ̀ kan.

column1: As opposed to this expert but subjective evaluation, we're trying to do the same thing, but from the molecular makeup of the fingerprint, and the two can work together.
column2: Ní àtakò sí àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ yìí ṣùgbọ́n ní aṣègbè ìgbéléwọ̀n, à ń gbìyànjú láti ṣe nǹkan kan náà, ṣùgbọ́n látara ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tó papọ̀ di òntẹ̀-ìka, méjééì sì lè ṣiṣẹ́ papọ̀.

column1: I did say that molecules are storytellers, so information on your health, your actions, your lifestyle, your routines, they're all there, accessible in a fingerprint.
column2: Mo sọ wí pé àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ jẹ́ asọ̀tàn, nítorí náà àwọn afitóni nípa ìlera yín, ìṣesí yín, ìgbeayé yín, iṣẹ́ yín, gbogbo wọn ló wà níbẹ̀, tó ṣe é wò nínú òntẹ̀-ìka kan.

column1: And molecules are the storytellers of our secrets in just a touch.
column2: Àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ jẹ́ asọ̀tàn nípa àṣírí wa pẹ̀lú ìfọwọ́kàn kan.

column1: Thank you.
column2: Ẹ seun.

column1: (Audience) Wow.
column2: (Àwọn ònwòran) Wow.

column1: Our immigration conversation is broken - here's how to have a better one
column2: Asọgbà ìwọlé látókère wa ti fọ́ - bí a ṣe lè ní èyí tó dára rè é.

column1: We often hear these days that the immigration system is broken.
column2: A máa ń gbọ́ lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà lásíkò yìí pé èto ìwọlé látókèèrè ti fọ́.

column1: I want to make the case today that our immigration conversation is broken and to suggest some ways that, together, we might build a better one.
column2: Mo fẹ́ ṣe ìpẹ̀jọ́ lónì pé àsọgbà ìwọlé látókèère wa ti fọ́ àti láti dábàá àwọn ọ̀nà tí, lápapọ̀, a lè pèsè èyí tó dára.

column1: In order to do that, I'm going to propose some new questions about immigration, the United States and the world, questions that might move the borders of the immigration debate.
column2: Láti lè ṣe ìyẹn, màá dábàá àwọn ìbéèrè tuntun nípa ìwọlé látókèèrè, orílẹ̀-ède United States àti àgbáyé, àwọn ìbéèrè tí ó lè sún àríyànjiyàn ibodè ìwọlé látókèrè.

column1: I'm not going to begin with the feverish argument that we're currently having, even as the lives and well-being of immigrants are being put at risk at the US border and far beyond it.
column2: Mi ò ní bẹ́rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àríyànjiyàn tó ń ṣòjòjò tí à ń ní lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí, kódà bí ìgbéayé àti ìgbáyégbádùn àwọn aṣíkiri ṣe ń wà nínú ewu ní enu-ibodè orílẹ̀-ède US àti jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

column1: Instead, I'm going to begin with me in graduate school in New Jersey in the mid-1990s, earnestly studying US history, which is what I currently teach as a professor at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tennessee.
column2: Dípò bẹ́ẹ̀, màá bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ara mi ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́-jáde ní New Jersey ní àrín àsìko 1990, tí mò ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa ìtan orílẹ̀-ède US, tó jẹ́ nǹkan tí mò ń kọ́ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ọjọ̀gbọ́n ní fásitì Vanderbilt ní Nashville, Tennessee.

column1: And when I wasn't studying, sometimes to avoid writing my dissertation, my friends and I would go into town to hand out neon-colored flyers, protesting legislation that was threatening to take away immigrants' rights.
column2: Nígbà tí mi ò bá kẹ́kọ̀ọ́, nígbà míràn láti sá fún kíkọ àpilẹ̀kọ àbọ̀ ìwádìí mi, èmi àti àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ mi máa wọ ìgboro lọ láti lọ fún àwọn ènìyàn ní ìwé-ìléwọ́ alárà-n-bara àwọ̀, tó ń fi èhónú han sí òfin tó ń dúkokò láti gba ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn aṣíkiri.

column1: Our flyers were sincere, they were well-meaning, they were factually accurate.
column2: Àwọn ìwé ìléwọ́ wa ṣòótọ́, wọ́n nítumọ̀ gidi, wọ́n péye ní òtítọ́.

column1: But I realize now, they were also kind of a problem.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n ó wá yémi báyìí, wọ́n tún fẹ́ẹ̀ jẹ́ oríṣi wàhálà kan.

column1: Here's what they said: "Don't take away immigrant rights to public education, to medical services, to the social safety net.
column2: Nǹkan tí wọ́n sọ rè é: “ẹ má gba ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn aṣíkiri sí ẹ̀kọ́ gbogbogbò, sí ètò ìlere, sí àwọ̀n ààbò àwùjọ.

column1: They work hard.
column2: Wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára.

column1: They pay taxes.
column2: Wọ́n ń sanwó-orí.

column1: They're law-abiding.
column2: Wọ́n ń tẹ̀lé òfin.

column1: They use social services less than Americans do.
column2: Wọ́n ò lo àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ àwùjọ tó bí àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America ṣe ń lò ó.

column1: They're eager to learn English, and their children serve in the US military all over the world.
column2: Wọ́n nífẹ̀ láti kọ́ ède gẹ̀ẹ́sì, àwọn ọmọ wọn sì ń sìnrú-ìlú nínú ikọ̀ ọmọ-ogun orílẹ̀-ède US káàkiri àgbáyé.

column1: " Now, these are, of course, arguments that we hear every day.
column2: “ Báyìí, àwọn wọ̀nyí ni, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn àríyànjiyàn tí à ń gbọ́ lójoojúmọ́.

column1: Immigrants and their advocates use them as they confront those who would deny immigrants their rights or even exclude them from society.
column2: Àwọn aṣíkiri àti àwọn agbẹnusọ wọn ń lò wọ́n láti fi kojú àwọn tí wọn yóò fi ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn aṣíkiri dú wọ́n tàbí tí wọ́n fẹ́ yọ wọ́n kúrò nínú àwùjọ.

column1: And up to a certain point, it makes perfect sense that these would be the kinds of claims that immigrants' defenders would turn to.
column2: Dé ìpele kan, ó mú ọpọlọ dání pé àwọn wọ̀nyí yóò jẹ́ irú àwíjàre tí àwọn tí wọ́n ń gbè lẹ́yìn àwọn aṣíkiri máa kọjú sí.

column1: But in the long term, and maybe even in the short term, I think these arguments can be counterproductive.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà pípẹ́, àti bóyá lásíkò díẹ̀, mo rò wí pé àwọn àríyànjiyàn wọ̀nyí lè díra wọn lọ́wọ́.

column1: Because it's always an uphill battle to defend yourself on your opponent's terrain.
column2: Torí ogun tó lágbára ló máa ń jẹ́ láti gbèja ara yín ní agbègbe alátakò yín.

column1: And, unwittingly, the handouts my friends and I were handing out and the versions of these arguments that we hear today were actually playing the anti-immigrants game.
column2: pẹ̀lú àìmọ̀kan, ìwé-ìléwọ́ tí èmi àti àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ mi ń fún àwọn ènìyàn àti ẹ̀dà àwọn àríyànjiyàn wọ̀nyí tí à ń gbọ́ lóni ń tayò atako-aṣíkiri ni.

column1: We were playing that game in part by envisioning that immigrants were outsiders, rather than, as I'm hoping to suggest in a few minutes, people that are already, in important ways, on the inside.
column2: À ń ta ayò yẹn lóríkè pẹ̀lú ojú-ìwòye pé aráàta ni àwọn aṣíkiri, yàtọ̀ sí pé, bí mo ṣe ń lérò láti dá lábà ní ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀, àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ti, ní àwọn ọ̀nà tó ṣe pàtàkì, wà nínú ilé tẹ́lẹ̀.

column1: It's those who are hostile to immigrants, the nativists, who have succeeded in framing the immigration debate around three main questions.
column2: Àwọn tí wọ́n ń dẹ́yẹsí àwọn aṣíkiri, àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú, tí wọ́n ti ṣàṣeyọrí níbi síso àríyànjiyàn ìwọlé látókèrè mọ́ kókó ìbéèrè mẹ́ta.

column1: First, there's the question of whether immigrants can be useful tools.
column2: Àkọ́kọ́, ìbéèrè kán wà nípa bóyá àwọn aṣíkiri lè di irinṣẹ́ tó wúlò.

column1: How can we use immigrants?
column2: Báwo la ṣe lè lo àwọn aṣíkiri?

column1: Will they make us richer and stronger?
column2: Ṣé wọ́n máa jé ká lówó ká sì tún lágbára síi?

column1: The nativist answer to this question is no, immigrants have little or nothing to offer.
column2: Ìdáhùn àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ ìlú sí ìbéèrè yìí ni rárá, àwọn aṣíkiri ní díẹ̀ tàbí wọn ò ní nǹkankan láti fún wa.

column1: The second question is whether immigrants are others.
column2: Ìbéèrè kejì ni wí pé bóyá àwọn aṣíkiri jẹ́ àwọn tókù.

column1: Can immigrants become more like us?
column2: Ǹjẹ́ àwọn aṣíkiri lè di ara wa?

column1: Are they capable of becoming more like us?
column2: Ṣé wọ́n níkàpá láti dàbi wa?

column1: Are they capable of assimilating?
column2: Ṣé wọ́n níkàpá láti farajọwá?

column1: Are they willing to assimilate?
column2: Ṣé wọ́n ṣe tán láti farajọwá?

column1: Here, again, the nativist answer is no, immigrants are permanently different from us and inferior to us.
column2: Níbí, lẹ́ẹ̀kan síi, ìdáhùn àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú ni rárá, àwọn aṣíkiri yátọ̀ pátápátá sí wa wọ́n sì kéré síwa.

column1: And the third question is whether immigrants are parasites.
column2: Ìbéèrè kẹ́ta ni bóyá àwọn aṣíkiri jẹ́ ajọ̀fẹ́.

column1: Are they dangerous to us?
column2: Ṣé wọ́n léwu fún wa?

column1: And will they drain our resources?
column2: Ṣé wọ́n máa gbọ́n ohun-àlùmọ́nì wa gbẹ?

column1: Here, the nativist answer is yes and yes, immigrants pose a threat and they sap our wealth.
column2: Níbí, ìdáhùn àwọn ọmọ ìlú ni bẹ́ẹ̀ ni àti bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn aṣíkiri lè fa ewu wọ́n sì ń gbọ́n ọrọ̀ọ wa gbẹ.

column1: I would suggest that these three questions and the nativist animus behind them have succeeded in framing the larger contours of the immigration debate.
column2: Máa dá a lábà wí pé àwọn ìbéèrè mẹ́ta wọ̀nyí àti ìpinnu àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú tó wà lẹ́yìn wọn ti ṣe aṣeyọrí níbi ṣíṣe àwọn igun ńlá nípa àríyànjiyàn ìwọlé látókèrè.

column1: These questions are anti-immigrant and nativist at their core, built around a kind of hierarchical division of insiders and outsiders, us and them, in which only we matter, and they don't.
column2: Àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí jẹ́ atako-àwọn aṣíkiri àti àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ ìlú paraku, tí wọ́n sopọ̀ mọ́ ìpín onípele àgbékà àwọn arálé àti aráàta, àwa àti àwọn, tó jẹ́ wí pé àwa la ṣe pàtàkì jùlọ, tí àwọn ò sì rí bẹ́ẹ̀.

column1: And what gives these questions traction and power beyond the circle of committed nativists is the way they tap into an everyday, seemingly harmless sense of national belonging and activate it, heighten it and inflame it.
column2: Nǹkan tó ń fún àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí ní òkìkí àti agbára tayọ ẹgbẹ́ àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú tí wọ́n ní àfọkànsìn ni bí wọ́n ṣe ń pín nínú òye àjọgbépọ̀ àpapọ̀ ojoojúmọ́ tí ò léwu tí wọ́n sì ń ṣàmúlò rẹ̀, tí wọ́n ń gbé e sókè tí wọ́n sì ń fún-un lágbára.

column1: Nativists commit themselves to making stark distinctions between insiders and outsiders.
column2: Àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú ti jọ̀wọ́ ara wọn fún ṣiṣe ìyàtọ̀ tó fojú hàn láàárín aráalé àti aráàta.

column1: But the distinction itself is at the heart of the way nations define themselves.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n ìyàtọ̀ náà fún ra rẹ̀ wà ní gbùngun ọ̀nà tí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ń gbà ṣe àpèjúwe ara wọn.

column1: The fissures between inside and outside, which often run deepest along lines of race and religion, are always there to be deepened and exploited.
column2: Ìyàtọ̀ tó wà láàárín inú àti ìta, to ṣe wí pé lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà o máa ń sá wọ ojú ọ̀nà ìran àti ẹ̀sìn, máa ń wà níbẹ̀ láti jinú àti láti di àmúlò.

column1: And that potentially gives nativist approaches resonance far beyond those who consider themselves anti-immigrant, and remarkably, even among some who consider themselves pro-immigrant.
column2: Ìyẹn sì ń fún àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ ìlú ní ọ̀nà-ìmúṣe alátapadà tayọ àwọn tí wọ́n ríra wọn bíi atako àwọn aṣíkiri, àti lílù lọ́gọ-ẹnu, kódà láàárín àwọn kan tí wọ́n ríra wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bi alátìlẹyìn àwọn aṣíkiri.

column1: So, for example, when Immigrants Act allies answer these questions the nativists are posing, they take them seriously.
column2: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, nígbà tí àwọn alátìlẹyìn ìwé-òfin àwọn aṣíkiri dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè tí àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú ń gbé jáde wọ̀nyí, wọ́n mú wọn lọ́kùkúdùn.

column1: They legitimate those questions and, to some extent, the anti-immigrant assumptions that are behind them.
column2: Wọ́n sọ àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí di òfin àti, dé àwọn àyè kan, ìmọ̀ọ́nú àwọn atako-aṣíkiri tí wọ́n wà lẹ́yìn wọn.

column1: When we take these questions seriously without even knowing it, we're reinforcing the closed, exclusionary borders of the immigration conversation.
column2: Bí a bá mú àwọn ìbéèrè wònyí lọ́kùnkúndùn láìnímọ̀ nípa ẹ̀, à ń ṣe ìwúrí fún títì, àyọkúrò àsọgbà ibodè ìwọlé látókèrè.

column1: So how did we get here?
column2: Torí náà báwo la ṣe débí?

column1: How did these become the leading ways that we talk about immigration?
column2: Báwo ni àwọn wọ̀nyí ṣe di ònà tó ń léwájú tí a fi ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ìwọlé látókèrè?

column1: Here, we need some backstory, which is where my history training comes in.
column2: Níbí, a nílò àwọn ìtàn-ìpìlẹ̀, tó jẹ́ ibi tí ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ ìtàn mi yóò ti wọlé.

column1: During the first century of the US's status as an independent nation, it did very little to restrict immigration at the national level.
column2: Lásíkò ọrún ọdún àkọ́kọ́ ipò orílẹ̀-ède US gẹ́gẹ́ bi orílẹ̀-ède olómìnira, ó ṣe díẹ̀ láti ṣe ìdíwọ́ ìwọlé látókèrè ní ìpele orílẹ̀-èdè.

column1: In fact, many policymakers and employers worked hard to recruit immigrants to build up industry and to serve as settlers, to seize the continent.
column2: Ní tòótọ́, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn aṣòfin àti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ń ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára láti gba àwọn aṣíkiri láti ṣẹ̀dá ilé-iṣẹ́ àti láti ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bi atẹ̀dó, láti gba ẹkùn náà.

column1: But after the Civil War, nativist voices rose in volume and in power.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n lẹ́yìn ogun abẹ́lé, ohùn àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú gókè ní yíyí àti ní agbára

column1: The Asian, Latin American, Caribbean and European immigrants who dug Americans' canals, cooked their dinners, fought their wars and put their children to bed at night were met with a new and intense xenophobia, which cast immigrants as permanent outsiders who should never be allowed to become insiders.
column2: Àwọn ilẹ̀ Asia, Latin America, Caribbean àti àwọn aṣíkiri ilẹ̀-Europe tí wọ́n gbé kòtò-ìdaminù àwọn ọmọ-ilẹ̀ America, tí wọ́n ń dáná alẹ́ wọn, tí wọ́n ń jagun wọn tí wọ́n sì ń rẹ àwọn ọmọ wọn tẹ́ lálẹ́ ni wọ́n ṣe alábàápàde ìbẹ̀ru aráàta tuntun tó le, tó pín àwọn aṣíkiri gẹ́gẹ́ bi aráàta pátápátá tí wọn ò gbọdọ̀ gbà láyè láti di aráalé.

column1: By the mid-1920s, the nativists had won, erecting racist laws that closed out untold numbers of vulnerable immigrants and refugees.
column2: Nígbà tí yó fi di àrín àsìko 1920, àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú ti borí, gbígbé òfin ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà dìde  ṣe agbétìsíta iye àwọn aṣíkiri tó kọ́gun-séwu àti àwọn ogúnléndé tí wọn ò sọ síta.

column1: Immigrants and their allies did their best to fight back, but they found themselves on the defensive, caught in some ways in the nativists' frames.
column2: Àwọn aṣíkiri àti àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn sapá wọn láti jà padà, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n bára wọn lẹ́ni tó ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn, wọ́n káwọn ní àwọn ọ̀nà kọ̀ọ̀kan nínú ìṣe àtìlẹ́yìn fún àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú.

column1: When nativists said that immigrants weren't useful, their allies said yes, they are.
column2: Nígbà tí àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú sọ wí pé àwọn aṣíkiri ò wúlò, àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn ní bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, wọ́n wúlò.

column1: When nativists accused immigrants of being others, their allies promised that they would assimilate.
column2: Nígbà tí àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú fi ẹ̀sùn kan àwọn aṣíkiri wí pé àwọn tókù niwọ́n, àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn ṣe àdéhùn pé wọ́n máa fara jọwọ́n.

column1: When nativists charged that immigrants were dangerous parasites, their allies emphasized their loyalty, their obedience, their hard work and their thrift.
column2: Nígbà tí àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú fẹ̀sùn kàn wọn pé àwọn aṣíkiri jẹ́ ajọ̀fẹ́ tó léwu, àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn ṣe ìfirinlẹ̀ ìjólóòótọ́ wọn, ìgbọ́ràn wọn, ìṣiṣẹ́ kára wọn àti àìnáwó-nínàkúnà wọn.

column1: Even as advocates welcomed immigrants, many still regarded immigrants as outsiders to be pitied, to be rescued, to be uplifted and to be tolerated, but never fully brought inside as equals in rights and respect.
column2: Kódà bí àwọn agbẹnusọ ṣe ń gba àwọn aṣíkiri mọ́ra, ọ̀pọ́ ṣì ń ka àwọn aṣíkiri sí aráàta tó yẹ kí wọ́n káànú, tó yẹ kí wọ́n dóòlà, tó yẹ kí wọ́n gbéga kí wọ́n sì gbà mọ́ra, ṣùgbọ́n tí wọn ò ní mú wọlé gẹ́gẹ́ bi adọ́gba ní ẹ̀tọ́ àti ọ̀wọ̀.

column1: After World War II, and especially from the mid-1960s until really recently, immigrants and their allies turned the tide, overthrowing mid-20th century restriction and winning instead a new system that prioritized family reunification, the admission of refugees and the admission of those with special skills.
column2: Lẹ́yìn ogun àgbáyé kejì, pàápàá jùlọ láti àrín àsìko 1960 yàtọ̀sí àìpẹ́ yìí, àwọn aṣíkiri àti àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn ń fa ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ padà sẹ́yìn, tí wọ́n fẹ́ ti ìdíwọ́ ọ̀rún ọdún àrín-ogún ṣubú àti ìborí dípo ètò tuntun tí yóò gbájúmọ́ ìkójọpọ̀ àwọn ẹbi, gbígba àwọn ogúnléndé àti gbígba àwọn tí wọ́n ní ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe tó yátọ̀.

column1: But even then, they didn't succeed in fundamentally changing the terms of the debate, and so that framework endured, ready to be taken up again in our own convulsive moment.
column2: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà náà, wọn ò ṣàṣeyọrí nínú ṣíṣe àyípadà ìpìlẹ̀ àwọn àdéhùn àríyànjiyàn náà, nítorí náà ẹ̀tò-ìgbésẹ̀ iṣẹ́ náà dúró, tó ṣetán láti di lílò padà ní àsìko ìparí titi wa.

column1: That conversation is broken.
column2: Àsọgbà yẹn ti fọ́.

column1: The old questions are harmful and divisive.
column2: Àwọn ìbéèrè àtijọ́ náà léwu àti ìpínyà.

column1: So how do we get from that conversation to one that's more likely to get us closer to a world that is fairer, that is more just, that's more secure?
column2: Báwo la ṣe fẹ́ kúrò láti àsọgbà yẹn sí èyí tó lè múwa súmọ́ ilẹ̀-àgbáyé kan tó jẹ́ oní déédé, tó jẹ́ adọ́gba, tí ò léwu púpọ̀?

column1: I want to suggest that what we have to do is one of the hardest things that any society can do: to redraw the boundaries of who counts, of whose life, whose rights and whose thriving matters.
column2: Mo fẹ́ dábàá wí pé nǹkan tí a ní láti ṣe jẹ́ ọ̀kan nínú àwọn nǹkan tó le tí àwùjọ kankan lè ṣe: láti ṣe àtúnyà àwọn enu-àlà ẹni tó ṣe pàtàkì, tí ìgbésí ayé rẹ̀, tí ẹ̀tọ rẹ̀ àti ìdàgbàsókè ṣe pàtàkì.

column1: We need to redraw the boundaries.
column2: A nílò láti ṣe àtúnyà àwọn enu-àlà náà

column1: We need to redraw the borders of us.
column2: A nílò láti ṣe àtúnyà àwọn ibodè wa.

column1: In order to do that, we need to first take on a worldview that's widely held but also seriously flawed.
column2: Láti lè ṣe ìyẹn, a nílò láti kọ́kọ́ gbájúmọ́ ojú-ìwòye tí àwọn ènìyàn ní ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n ti ní akùdé gidi gan-an.

column1: According to that worldview, there's the inside of the national boundaries, inside the nation, which is where we live, work and mind our own business.
column2: Gẹ́gẹ́ bi ojú-ìwòye yẹn, inú àwọn enu-àlà àpapọ̀ wa, nínú orílẹ̀-èdè náà, tó jẹ́ ibi tí à ń gbé, tí a tí ń ṣiṣẹ́ tí a sì ń mọ̀wọn arawa.

column1: And then there's the outside; there's everywhere else.
column2: Ìta rẹ̀ náà wà; ibi gbogbo náà wà.

column1: According to this worldview, when immigrants cross into the nation, they're moving from the outside to the inside, but they remain outsiders.
column2: Gẹ́gẹ́ bi ojú-ìwòye yìí, nígbà tí àwọn aṣíkiri bá ta kọ́sọ́ sí orílẹ̀-èdè náà, wọ́n ń gbéra láti ìta sínú ilé, sùgbọ́n wọn ó ṣì jẹ́ aráàta.

column1: Any power or resources they receive are gifts from us rather than rights.
column2: Èyíkéyìí agbára tàbí ohun-èlò tí wọ́n bá gbà gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹ̀bùn látọ̀dọ wa yàtọ̀sí àwọn ẹ̀tọ wọn

column1: Now, it's not hard to see why this is such a commonly held worldview.
column2: Ní báyìí, kò ṣòro láti rí èrèdí tí èyí fi jẹ́ irú ojú-ìwòye tí àwọn ènìyàn ní tọ wọ́pọ̀.

column1: It's reinforced in everyday ways that we talk and act and behave, down to the bordered maps that we hang up in our schoolrooms.
column2: Wọ́n ṣe ìwúrí fún-un ní àwọn ọ̀nà ojoojúmọ́ bí a ṣe ń sọrọ̀ àti bí a ṣe ń ṣe àti bí a ṣe ń húwà, débi àwòrán ẹnubodè tí a fi kọ́ sókè nínú àwọn yàra-ilé-ẹ̀kọ wa.

column1: The problem with this worldview is that it just doesn't correspond to the way the world actually works, and the way it has worked in the past.
column2: Ìṣòro tó wà pẹ̀lú ojú-ìwòye yìí ni wí pé kò papọ̀ mọ́ ònà tí ilẹ̀ àgbáyé ń gbà ṣiṣẹ́, àti ọ̀nà tí ó ti gbà ṣiṣẹ́ sẹ́yìn.

column1: Of course, American workers have built up wealth in society.
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn òṣìṣẹ ilẹ̀ America ti pèsè ọrọ̀ ní àwùjọ.

column1: But so have immigrants, particularly in parts of the American economy that are indispensable and where few Americans work, like agriculture.
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni àwọn aṣíkiri, pàtàkì jùlọ ní apá kan ọrọ̀-ajé ilẹ̀ America tí ò ṣe é fẹ́kù àti ibi tí díẹ̀ nínú àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America ti ń ṣiṣẹ́, bíi iṣẹ́ àgbẹ̀.

column1: Since the nation's founding, Americans have been inside the American workforce.
column2: Látígbà tí wọ́n ti dá orílẹ̀-èdè náà sílẹ̀, ni àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America ti wà nínú ẹgbẹ́-òṣìṣẹ́ ilẹ̀ America.

column1: Of course, Americans have built up institutions in society that guarantee rights.
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America ti kọ́ àwọn ilé-isẹ́ sínú àwùjọ tó ń ṣe ìdánilójú ẹ̀tọ́.

column1: But so have immigrants.
column2: Bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni àwọn aṣíkiri.

column1: They've been there during every major social movement, like civil rights and organized labor, that have fought to expand rights in society for everyone.
column2: Wọ́n ti wà níbẹ̀ lásíkò kókó ìtẹ̀síwájú àwùjọ, bíi ẹ̀tọ́ ará-ìlú àti ẹgbẹ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́, tí a ti jà láti fẹ ẹ̀tọ́ lójú nínú àwùjọ fún gbogbo ènìyan.

column1: So immigrants are already inside the struggle for rights, democracy and freedom.
column2: Nítorí náà àwọn aṣíkiri ti wà nínú ìjà fún ẹ̀to, ìjọba àwarawa àti òmìnira

column1: And finally, Americans and other citizens of the Global North haven't minded their own business, and they haven't stayed within their own borders.
column2: Lákòtán, àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America àti àwọn àwọn ọmọ-ìlú tókù ní Global North ò mọ̀wọn ara wọn, wọn ò sì tíì dúró sáàrín ibódè tiwọn.

column1: They haven't respected other nations' borders.
column2: Wọn ò tíì ní ìbọ́wọ̀ fún enubodè àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tókù.

column1: They've gone out into the world with their armies, they've taken over territories and resources, and they've extracted enormous profits from many of the countries that immigrants are from.
column2: Wọ́n ti jáde lọ sínú ayé pẹ̀lú àwọn ọmọ-ogun wọn, wọ́n ti gba ìṣàkóso àwọn ilẹ̀ àti ohun àlùmọ́nì, wọ́n sì ti yọ èrè tó pọ̀ lára orílẹ̀-èdè púpọ̀ tí àwọn aṣíkiri ti wá.

column1: In this sense, many immigrants are actually already inside American power.
column2: Ni ti èyí, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn aṣíkiri kulẹ̀ ti wà nínú agbára ilẹ̀ America tẹ́lẹ̀.

column1: With this different map of inside and outside in mind, the question isn't whether receiving countries are going to let immigrants in.
column2: Pẹ̀lú àwòrán inú àti ìta orílẹ̀-èdè lẹ́mi wọn, ìbéèrè náà kìí ṣe wí pé bóyá gbígba àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè wọ̀nyí yóò jẹ́ kí àwọn aṣíkiri ó wọlé.

column1: They're already in.
column2: Wọ́n kulẹ̀ ti wọlé.

column1: The question is whether the United States and other countries are going to give immigrants access to the rights and resources that their work, their activism and their home countries have already played a fundamental role in creating.
column2: Ìbéèrè náà ni pé bóyá orílẹ̀-ède United States àti àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tókù máa fún àwọn aṣíkiri ní àn àǹfààní fàní sí àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ àti ohun àlùmọ́nì tí iṣẹ́ wọn, ìjàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ wọn àti àwọn orílẹ̀-ède wọn ti kó ipa pàtàkì nínú ìṣẹ̀da rẹ̀.

column1: With this new map in mind, we can turn to a set of tough, new, urgently needed questions, radically different from the ones we've asked before -- questions that might change the borders of the immigration debate.
column2: Pẹ̀lú àwòran orílẹ̀-èdè tuntun yìí lọ́kàn, a lè kọjú sí sẹ́ẹ́tì àwọn ìbéèrè líle, tuntun, tí a nílò kíákíá, tó yátọ̀ gédéngbé sí àwọn tí a ti bẹ̀rè tẹ́lẹ̀ -- àwọn ìbéèrè tó lè ṣe àyípadà àríyànjiyàn enubodè ìwọlé látókèrè.

column1: Our three questions are about workers' rights, about responsibility and about equality.
column2: Àwọn ìbéèrè mẹ́ta wa jẹ́ nípa ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́, nípa ojúṣe àti nípa ìdọ́gba.

column1: First, we need to be asking about workers' rights.
column2: Àkọ́kọ́, a nílò láti máa bèrè nípa ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́.

column1: How do existing policies make it harder for immigrants to defend themselves and easier for them to be exploited, driving down wages, rights and protections for everyone?
column2: Báwo ni àwọn ìpinnu tó wà nílẹ̀ ṣe ń jẹ́ kó le fún àwọn aṣíkiri láti gbèja arawọn kó sì rọrùn fún wọn láti lò wọn nílò-kulò, wíwa owó-iṣẹ́ wálẹ̀, ẹ̀tọ́ àti ìdáààbòbò fún gbogbo ènìyàn?
